reviewText:
I am blown away.
I had this game for a long time in my library, I loved Mafia 1, everyone told me Mafia 2 is not as good, I did not get it.
Some years later I get it as steam gift, ignored it a long time, tried it now and I am totally shocked how good this game is.

It starts good, it gets better and it stays so until the very end.

You just do the main story (14 hours for me), drive around in your stolen cars and are all the time looking the wonderful graphics and listen to the songs from the radio.
From time to time you get into fistfights which are fun too.
And then the firefights, they are... you knew it? fun too! :)
You can really use cover, shoot from cover, use pistols, colts, sub machine guns or a shot gun. Grenades and the like exist too but I did not really use them a lot. I LOVE my shot gun.

So what is there in the game:
- story: very good
- graphics: very good
- sound: very good
- fist fights: good
- gun fights: very good
- driving: good

And if that is really not enough for you: there are playboy magzines to find which each show one picture. This alone is a reason to get the game. Ok, not really, but I like it nevertheless :)

I really think that most older gamers who did ever enjoy a shooter will enjoy this game too.

Now I am waiting for a special on steam to get the DLCs:
- Jimmy's Vendetta" and
- "Joe's Adventure"
which tell stories and seem to allow free roaming.

I have to repeat
date: I was blown away by this game
recommended:
I did not expect such an old game to be that good.


update: I do not like the DLCs
hoursPlayed: don't waste your money for the DLCs. But get the main game!"

reviewText:
Mafia 2 places you in the shoes of Vito Scaletta a boy who's parents emigrated to the USA - specifically the fictional city of Empire Bay (fashioned after NYC) - from Sicily. Think of Mafia 2 as the best of your favorite gangster movies only much longer and with you in control of the action and you'll get an idea of what the game is really like.

Gameplay is reminiscent of GTA only without the auto-targeting aspect. At its core Mafia 2 is a 3rd person over the shoulder shooter.The game takes place in 1940's - 1950's America so expect period guns (M1945, Tommy Gun's, shotguns); vehicles (not actual licensed cars but closely based on period autos); and clothing. The driving mechanics in Mafia 2 in my opinion are a vast improvement over the on-ice feel that the vehicles in GTA IV featured. Driving insane speeds is possible but expect a quick death if you crash (on hard difficulty anyway).

Unlike other open-world or sandbox games, the focus of Mafia 2 is the main story. Admittedly Mafia 2 is short on sidequests and minigames. This is generally a problem if you go in expecting a GTA clone. Mafia 2 is most definitely not that. Personally I found the focus on the story refreshing. Instead of distractions like pizza delivery missions or other time wasters, Mafia 2 is about story driven events that include everything from jewelry store heists to covert missions planting explosives to assassinate a rival family member.

While Mafia 2 doesn't feature any type of online gameplay there are plenty of collectibles in-game including Playboy centerfold magazines (complete with nudity) and wanted posters to keep you occupied. I highly recommend this title!

reviewText:
One of my favorite games, The story line is amazing, I can't stop playing this over and over.

Graphics - Especially for a 2010 game, the graphics are amazing, you can get some really amazing scenery in this, Not quite on the level of Skyrim, But looking over the map is very nice to do :)
Gameplay - The gameplay is very easy to get used to, from stealth missions to full out combat, this game gives you some brilliant gunfights, robberies, boss missions and car chases. The police evasion is a very tedius, but over all more fun method, Unlike games like GTA where, you loose the police and you can then drive past them with a car thats smashed up, covered in blood with bullet holes in it and they won't beat an eye, this game requires you to get your car fixed up, new plates added, and a change of clothes to get the police to not suspect anything next time they see you.
Controls - The controls are very nicely done, as far as combat is concerned, the aiming, the slow motion, everything is brilliant. As for driving, They have gone for realism with it, Some people might like it, I wasn't really a fan of it, it takes a bit of time to get used to meaning I spent most of the beginning of the game crashing into things and getting shot up in no time, but with a bit of practice you become a good driver in no time, But then again, its realistic, its how cars where back then.
Story - One of my favorite stories of all time, I can't really describe it, but you will have to play it to find out. Its a whole story of betrayal, emotion, sadness but at the same time, partying, trust, money. The story is a crazy mix of family life and gang life. The best way to describe it, is sort of on par with Breaking bad. A hardworking man taking up illegal tasks to help support his family.

I can't actually believe I got this game for free by voting in a contest, The fact that it was a free giveaway made me think quite poorly of this game and it took me a while to get round to playing it, and that was a big regret. This is by far one of my favorite games.

reviewText:
Mafia II. Note that I have, at this moment in time, never before played Mafia I.
Although I have played other such titles, for example Mafia Wars, The Godfather games, Omerta City of Gangsters and of course GTA and also Saints Row.
This game, has by far one of the most gripping main story lines I have come across for this genre. (Personally)
I played this first on Xbox 360, and I have many many hours clocked.

Now I shall tell you about a few features.

Car mechanics;
the driving is lovely and realistic. No manual gear changing or first person head turning ( I belive there is a fine working modification for first person) but everything works smoothly as it should. You can turn on or off a speedomiter on as far as I know all cars. There is also an option to turn on or off realistic driving ( more slipping when it's wet with rain and snow, realistic breaking, that sort of thing. ) Car damage is very well done and there is a car mechanic shop at your service, as well as a few other types of shops : ) you as the player cannot shoot out of windows as far as I know without some sort of modification to the game, but other NPCs in the car can and will if need be ( if they use a gun normally  xD ) You can open the bonnet and boot of most cars, which is a lovely feature :) they really did well on the cars, I mean you can take the hubcaps off from damage.. taking out the lights and tyres is very fun and rewarding.. shooting through the windows is very nice.. the bumpers bounce about nicely when they partly come apart.. spinning out and drifting is very nice, aaandd, you can shoot the sirens to stop them xD! There are many many vechicles to see and drive, from armoured vans and trucks to small sports cars and hotrods : D.
Next is the violence mechanics;
Shooting is very well done, you can also punch up enemies with your fists.. the fighting is well done!
You can kill someone instantly if you shoot the head, so there is minor locational damage, and all animations are very good. There is blood also.
There is a good cover system, alowing you to take cover on most objects however they are. You can also destroy most objects as you please.
Atmosphere;
It feels veryy genuine. The music, crisp textures and wonderful lighting provides a truly nineteen thirtys to seventys feel. Something perhaps out of The Italian Job, or a James Bond movie..
There are many many songs out on the few radio stations.. from home radio to car radio you can listen all the time :D
Oh, voice acting is absolutly top notch. For the most part there are no hiccups!
You can dress differently, answer phones and use rest rooms, buy drinks and food, and take a stroll out and about.

I love this game. I hope you will or do too :)

reviewText:
Mafia II is a game that should be played mainly for its Story. The pace is great from the very beginning were it tells the Story of your character when you were younger and how you end up doing what you are doing. You start doing little jobs here and there to get some money to pay a debt left by a family member. Right from the start you feel that family is the most important thing but as you go deeper and deeper you realize that it's hard to not involve the ones you care because of your decisions. As you go through the Story you experience a better life with better cars, a better house and most of all, more money, however, the main character wonders if this is what he really wanted to have when you end up doing things you may not feel proud of.

When you start the game it's Winter time. It's cold and it snows a lot. The roads are slippery and covered in snow. After some certain events I won't spoil, you return to the city during Spring time where everything feels more alive. More bright colors, people driving their convertible cars and the streets are finally filled with green grass without any sign of snow. As always, it's great to drive around town when it starts to rain. Feels good. This was a good idea to give you the feeling that time is passing. It's always interesting to see a different season after some time when playing a game.

The visuals are really well done. Facial animations are really good and they made a great job with the details on the characters faces such little scars or others imperfections". reviewText:
Three disclaimers before this review:

1. I am a big RPG fan.

2. I love story-driven games.

3. If you hate to read words, then skip to the end.

I blew through the main campaign in Mafia II in just over 15 hours, and I would say that my overall rating would land very close to the Metacritic average. I'd give it a C+ or B-

Most reading this already know what kind of a game Mafia II is. For those just starting their investigation, it's a 3P action shooter/driver. There will be inevitable comparisons to the Grand Theft Auto series, but outside of the big city setting and gunplay, it really isn't. All preconceived notions there should be thrown to the wind.

What I liked about Mafia II:

1. I loved the story driven game. The writers did a good job of tying seemingly disparate scenes together later in the game. And there was enough character development to at least *begin* to become emotionally tied (or repulsed) by certain main characters. More on that later.

2. Dialogue. You're going to have quite a few cutscenes in this game. I personally thought they were well dispersed and well-done. Voice acting is *excellent* and dialogue writing is good (not great, more on that later).

3. I loved the shooting mechanics. Some will disagree strongly, but I played with an XBOX 360 controller, and I found the shooting to be fairly true to real life. You can definitely nail down plenty of head shots, but you're going to have to work to be able to do so. Pistols were actually my favorite in-game, as I could (when able) concentrate on one enemy at a time. I also loved that NPCs responded to my firing. They would behave differently when I was firing. It came in handy later in the game with larger fields of oppenents.

4. I really liked the relationship with police. They seemed to ramp up their vigilance accordingly, and occasionally, they (realistically) interrupted gunfights with other parties to try and bring order. Sometimes, this was a welcome backup"

reviewText:
This game has an amazing storyline, great gameplay and an enjoyable atmosphere.

As Vito Scarletta you discover yourself joining the Italian Mafia after getting out of the war for a couple of years. Roaming the streets of Empire Bay had its limitations on what you could do and what you couldn't. It's free roam felt slightly restricted as it's not as open as games such as the GTA (Grand Theft Auto) series. The open world felt quite similar to Sleeping Dogs in a way.

The 1940s-1950s setting didn't feel like a new era to me as it reminded me of games such as Driver which was one of many favourite memories. The music in the game didn't appeal to me too much as I'm not really a fan of the 50s music.

The customization with vehicles and character clothing is very limited, although it was enough for me to enjoy. Graphics were decent and didn't get me too worried about it.

I encounted a bug or two while playing the game and a graphical problem which did get quite frustrating to a point. The checkpoint system in this game also felt like a very perfunctory attempt by 2K Games which would have added about an hour of unnecessary playtime.

Gameplay felt similar to GTA in a lot of ways which I was able to adapt to easily. There were quite a few mundane missions which consisted of driving to locations, etc. Getting into a gun fight in this game really felt riviting and awesome! Along with everything else, the storyline is what kept me going through this game. It basically covers the game up from a lot of it's flaws.

Definately a game worth playing if you are in for a good storyline and pumping gun fights.

reviewText:
Ad-notation #1: THIS GAME IS AVAILABLE ON THE STEAM STORE AGAIN! THESE ARE WONDERFUL NEWS TO EVERYONE WHO DIDN'T TRY OUT THIS GAME YET!
Ad-notation #2: I am giving this title a GOTY for 2010. Even in 2016, it's still a masterpiece.
Basic Information
Title: Mafia II
Genre: Action
Developer: 2K Czech
Publisher: 2K Games
Release Date: 22 Mar, 2011

General Impression
Mafia II is a game that is more than great! It also has a big impact of emotions, when you see its final scene you are likely to cry, or to be sorry, because Joe is taken away from Vito. In this game you have 15 chapters, 50 playboys, 250 wanted posters and so many collectibles. In the free roam time you can take a car and drive through the beautiful city of Empire Bay (New York City). You can also fight with the cops or with the gangsters, you can have both fists and gun fights. There are a lot of shops, alike: clothing store, upgrading cars workshop, gun shop, restaurants and bars. I played it very much because I felt like this is the perfect game for me. Shooting is very nice and it's also comfortable. Driving cars is awesome, because it's easy to handle any car. This game is similar to Grand Theft Auto IV, but I consider it better made.

Graphics
The graphics of this game are beautifully designed, being somehow close to the reality, because this game takes place in Empire Bay, a copy after New York City. The nature things are well designed, such as trees, the sky, the grass, flowers, etc. The buildings seem a lot with the real ones from New York City, which is enjoyable. The cars are just art, I love the way they are designed, they make you feel like you're in the old times. The sky varies from temperature, being sunny, cloudy, etc.

Atmosphere
The atmosphere of this game varies from being inside you own house to being outside or in a restaurant/building. When you're driving, the police has a very well made AI, because when you go beyond the legal limit or crashing into another car, they will fine you. On bridges/highways you can drive with 70 MPH, and in the city only with 40 MPH. In the cities, you may find a lot of buildings, roads, people, stores, nature things, etc. Unfortunately, you can't enter most buildings, the ones being accessible are your flats/houses and stores. It tends to be an open world game, even though the missions tell you exactly where to go, without any side quests. In the DLCs, you choose the missions in what order you like, being better for Open-World guys. This game has both countryside part, but mostly city part.

Audio
The soundtrack of this game were made by Matus Siroky and Adam Kuruc, 2 well known composers. While driving, you are able to switch the radio station to 3 big channels. They deliver music and news. The outside sounds are pretty much the noise of cars, people who are talking, and even nature sounds, such as birds, winds, etc. When you're in a building, you can mostly hear car horns. During the missions, soundtracks will play, all of them completing the game's Original Soundtrack. The bullets' sounds are also realistic, as well as the engine noise of the cars.

Gameplay
The gameplay is about a young guy Vito, who accomplishes missions, such as killing enemies, eliminating important bosses, and mostly anything related to killing. Vito has a large selection of guns where to choose from, such as machine guns, rifles, pistols, grenades and his own fists. Vito can run very quick forever, unlikely in other games, where stamina is not unlimited. His health recovers pretty fast, depending on the difficulty. On hard, you aren't able to see where enemies are located on the minimap, so that you have to spot them. The more your health drops, the more likely it won't sit at 100% forever. It will come lower and lower, snacks and drinks can fully recover his health. Both gunfights and boxing are very fun. Driving cars feels very awesome, just think when you listen to old but gold music and driving through the New York City. It's just a great feeling.

Story
The story is about a young guy called Vittorio Antonio Scalleta (Vito Scalleta) who came from Sicily in USA with his poor family. His parents were poor, living his early life in a poorneighborhood, where he met Joe. When they both get 18 years old, they tried to rob a bank. Joe escaped from the police, but Vito didn't. He had to choose between jail or going to World War 2. He chose World War 2, which is a mission in the first chapter. Vito is taken as a soldier in Sicily, participating in the Husky Operation. He got shot, so he got back to America. In chapter 2, Joe manages to keep Vito home, getting him a car and a new place to live, his own house. Through the 15 chapters, Vito will take part in missions through the whole Empire Bay, helping his buddies, Joe Barbaro and Heny Tomasino. He will have to do a lot of choices, killing a lot of people, and generally having a pretty sad life. I won't spoil the ending, because the story wouldn't be nice while knowning the ending.

Engines
The engines on this game are well optimized, I haven't met any bugs or crashes, neither screen freezes. The people's movements are realistic, depending on the situation, moving calm or either running out from the firefight. The car movement feels very realistic, the crashing is also very accurate. The water always flows, but when you fire bullets in it, it will start shacking. You can also go with your car in the water, resulting in a respawn back on the ground. The nature objects seem very nice, especially trees, which always shake because of the wind, etc. This game can be run even on pretty old computers, which I consider very important, looking at the fact that this game is complex.

Strong PointsVery nice graphics for 2010
Good and emotional story
Good gameplay and feeling
Very good engines and movements
Very rare to none crashes or bugs
You have a lot of cars to ride
You have a lot of weapons
Very big surface to explore in many ways
You can earn a lot of cash to spend in stores
Weak PointsThe ending is very vaguely presented
No side quests / additional missions
No multiplayer, the biggest disadvantageGeneral Ratings
Graphics: 9/10
Atmosphere: 9/10
Audio: 10/10
Engines: 9.5/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Story: 10/10

Personal Rating: 9.41/10

Note: All ratings are being given in function of the game's releasing year.

reviewText:
- 8 / 10 -

Nice story based action TPS. Story is linear yet rather compelling with some scenes / missions intersecting with the original Mafia story line, quite a nice touch there. Environment & graphics are great & really captures the mid-40's to early 50's expertly, with authentic to era music, vehicles, weapons & clothing. Although besides the hunt for easter eggs there's very little incentive to stray from the main story line & not a lot happening if you do. It's an immersive open-world with the freedom to do but a few things. Voice acting is good.

Combat mechanics feel quite good & are overall rather satisfying, the cover system is fluid & practical. Good melee fighting mechanics, however very basic. Nice stealth system, yet is only optional for a couple of missions. The driving feels good, but does get a bit repetitive. The AI is mostly quite sophisticated & seems to offer randomised  events purely for spectation appeal.

Overall it's a good title well worth a once over. If you enjoyed the first one, then here's more of the same.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Mafia II
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: Action; Adventure; Story Rich; Sandbox; Open World
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 14-40 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWMan! what a fun little game this is.  It really feels like you are playing through a mafia movie, or moreso a season of a show akin to The Sopranos.  This is mostly a great story-driven experience set in a sandbox, more than it is a traditional sandbox game.

Something about Mafia II is just charming in a way that makes it really fun even though there is nothing groundbreaking about it.  The story is great, in my opinion, and the voice acting is beyond solid; and the simple things like the different atmospheres of the different chapters (due to weather, time period, etc.) keep you enticed with the game even though it may have comparably less features than other sandbox games like it.

If you just play through the main story it can feel like the sandbox is tiny, but it really is quite large.  If you like collectibles and hunt down the wanted posters, or just wander around, there is really quite a large world to explore.

There are some flaws, but they are mostly insignificant and easily ignored, and nothing really that damning.  If you want to play on hard the checkpoint system may prove a little frustrating but just make sure you go very slow, and if you play on easy you really shouldn't die at all so you can focus on enjoying the story.

Basically, if you've played a sandbox game like this, then you have already experienced all the gameplay this has to offer.  But if you are looking to experience a good story in a game, or simply want another new sandbox to explore, or maybe both: I can say you will enjoy Mafia II for sure.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Really enjoyed Mafia II

The atmosphere is similiar to L A Noire since they both take place during the end of WWII.

As Vito who doesnt want to become a worker like his father, working only for a small sum of bucks at the harbor you commit smaller robberies with your friend Joe till the police busts you and you are left with the option either to join the army or end up in prison.
The intro of the story takes place on a battlefield in Italy where you are able to learn the games mechanics and practise shooting. An injury however will give you the chance to rest a few weeks back in Empire Bay where your mother and sister live. Joe however uses his contacts to hand you over the neccessary papers to get out of the military service.
After he welcomes you and picks you up for a small drink and sends you home, you are fee to discover the open world.

The open world

is pretty alive as there are different weather effects such as snow, rain, sunshine etc and there is a day night circle but it will only shift when you begin a mew mission.
There are a lot of different npcs doing a lot of different things and remain quite chatty or angry if you bump into them. Some will get out of the car just to curse you if you have caused an accident.
If you missbehave for example you are speeding, the police will take action and persue you, however they are far more tolerant than the officers from GTA. If you stop and wait till they come to your window, you can pay a fee and they will let you go.
At certain spots you can watch the railway go by, ships cruising on the sea and riverside or even airplanes crossing the sky. The sounds contribute a lot to the atmosphere and change according to the place you travel.

Visually the game still keeps up with current games and only a few textures might reveal that the game was released a few years back.

There are 3 different radio stations you can listen to or turn off the radio if you rather enjoy your own music.

The map is not that big and sadly some features like public transport is cut from the final version of the game which is really dissappointing since the map could have been even more alive that way. You could have used taxis buses or even the subway as a passanger and probably travel a bit faster from a to b.
There are some buildings you can enter for example burgershops to regain some more heatlh, clothes shops to change your outfit and gas stations to buy gas for your vehicle.
You also will have a place to live which however is often changing during the events of the story.
Some quest related buildings are only accessible during the story mode.
_____________________________________________________________________________

The missions

are often different from eachother, adding a lot fun to the gameplay. However during the end of the game I and a lot of other players had the impression the devs had too much pressure to keep up the release date and the missions become somewhat plain and routine.
You can also finish missions in different ways and sometimes have a different outcome for example if you have to break into a building and open a safe you either can rush in and shoot your way out running from the cops or you can sneak in stealthkill or avoid the guards, move to the basement, turn off the alarm and open the safe without any noise to leave silently. This will also affect the cash you earn at the end.
You can fight unarmed or with a large selection of different firearms. The combat is really fluent and also the dodging to avoid enemy hits or bullets works mostly fine.

I wont spoiler about the story even though the game is quite old and it also depends on ones taste anyway. If you like the Italo mafia movies shown on TV you wont be dissappointed for sure. The English voice cast is pretty good and I also think they did a good job with the German voicecast. Twists within the plot keep the story interesting and lets you want to finish the game to its end.

The dlcs are mostly included now in the so called directors cut edition. Jimmys Vendetta and the Betrayal of Jimmy do sadly not feature a movie based plot which was included in the base game but instead offer mission spots arround the 1953s Empire Bay map. The NPCS mostly are visualized by an imagine and a text stating whats the story about and what you have to do.

If you still dont have Mafia II and cant get it on Steam, try to search the net or Gamestop to try it out.

reviewText:
So, if you're looking for:
- open-world game where you can freely roam around,
- sandbox type of a game where you can do so many fun, trivial activities,
- a game where you do side jobs involving criminal activities for money,
- or basically GTA clones...

...Then this game is not for you.
There might be cars to steal and freedom of exploration between missions, but compared to GTA this is a more story-driven game at heart. So while it might looked like one, it is in fact NOT a GTA clone at all.

But if what you're looking for is a 3rd person shooter with lovable characters and great storyline that perfectly captures that '40s-'60s American pop-culture and atmosphere, then yes, this is absolutely the perfect game for you.

reviewText:
Played through it three times on console. Had to play through it again on PC.

Pros:
+ Top notch voice acting and story telling. Excellent plot and narriative.
+ Characters are memorable, likable, hilarious, and when appropriate, lamentable.
+ World is super atmospheric and a believable showcase of the 1940's and 50's in both summer and winter periods.
+ Shooting is fun and the decent variety of guns all have a heavy impact.
+ Cars are beautiful and responsive. Very enjoyable to drive and customize.
+ Stealth sections are pretty simple but neat, though there are too few.
+ Graphics, textures, and lighting are decent for their age.
+ Extensive licensed soundtrack.
+ Collectibles in this game are magezines with indecent ladies in them.

Cons:
- Not a lot to do in the open world, kind of a tease.
- So. Much. Driving. Imagine GTA IV, but you can't use a taxi cab to fast travel anywhere.
- While fist-fighting is a little neat, it was meant to be a niche for this game and isn't all that fleshed out.
- Sudden, cliff-hanger ending. This game never reached the length the devs wanted it to be (Fifteen chapters short of their goal of forty. Game takes about 10 hours to beat if rushing). Some of the dev-proposed endings are circulating on the internet if you want closure.

Short of GTA IV, best open-world game I've ever played. One of the best stories and in-game worlds as well.

My god this was great. I bought it for the hell of just buying it, thinking i probably wouldn't touch it for a couple weeks. But thankfully i played it.

Story:
The story of this game is great. It will keep you hooked on playing it until you finish the game. The only downside to it is that it is pretty short. Around 9-10 hours depending on if you want to find the wanted posters or playboy magazines. (Or if you decide to buy the DLC)

Gameplay:
The gameplay was great for a 3rd person shooter. Driving is actually enjoyable unlike GTA IV. The game ran buttery smooth on my rig straight out of the box and no ini file modifications needed.

Graphics:
The graphics aren't exactly the greatest but they are by no means ugly. The faces of some characters will look kinda like they haven't loaded in the textures but that is their actual texture.

Sound:
Great sound track from the era. Fallout players will notice some songs from Fallout are in this. Cars, guns and explosives have great sound effects. The voice acting in this is amazing.

Final Thoughts:
For what i paid, it was worth every cent. One of the better games i have played in a while since sleeping dogs. The only noticeable downsides to it for me was the shortness of the story and the lack of a free roam mode.

reviewText:
An offer you can't refuse.
Sorry! I had to :)

Anyway, if you're looking for over-the-top fun and gameplay like in GTA or Saints Row, you won't get it here. This game's main focus is the story and the characters. You'll more often than not feel like you're playing a movie and waiting for another cutscene. Mafia 2 takes place during and after the 2nd world war and follows the story of Vito Scalleta and his best friend Joe Barbaro as they get involved with the Mafia. Without spoiling too much, the game takes some inspiration from the classic mafia movies, like The Godfather and The Goodfellas. I must also admit that I shed some tears on more than one occasion throughout the game. If you played the first Mafia, you'll also find a nod to the main character in one chapter, which recreates a certain event that happened in the first one.

Most of the Mafia II takes place in the fictional city of Empire Bay, which I think is based on New York and is fully explorable by the player. You are able to go pretty much anywhere with your vast collection of classic cars. The gunplay consists of using the cover-system and a variety of authentic weapons from that era, like MP40s, Thompsons and many more. The melee combat, while not on par with Sleeping Dogs or Batman games, is pretty good and challenging.

While the game is athmospheric and recreates the 40s and 50s very well, I must say that I'm dissapointed with the inconsistencies regarding the texture quality, most of it is good, but some things look considerably worse and can sometimes break the immersion. The game also suffers from some pretty noticable object pop-in. But, this game is one of the few, that does the depth of field right, I usually don't like DOF, but in this game it was very pretty. Also, the first part of the game takes place during the winter and the second part is during the summer, so It freshens up the game a bit.

If you're planing on buying it, you can safely purchase the base game without the DLC, which is more or less the cosmetic stuff. There are 2 'expansions', one of them has no story whatsoever and is very arcady (Jimmy's Vendetta) and the other one (Joe's Adventures) only has 1 mission which ties in to the main story.

In conclusion, if you like story rich games, like The Last of Us, Grand Theft Auto IV, Wolfenstein The New Order and so on,
or if you like classic movies about the Mafia and awesome Italian accents, then by all means, get this game. You will not be disapointed. But if you're the type that skips all the cutscenes and doesn't care about the plot, then this game is not for you.


(By the way, don't be fooled by my playtime, I've beat this game 2 or 3 times, before I was into supporting the developers" thing
date: if you know what I mean. Once I got it for 'free' on my PS+
recommended: I didn't feel the need to buy it again on Steam
hoursPlayed: so I pirated on PC. For that I'm deeply ashamed and will probably buy Mafia III as soon as it comes out.)"

reviewText:
Born the son of a poor immigrant, Vito is a beaten down Italian American who is trying to secure his piece of the American Dream. Looking to escape the life of poverty that consumed his childhood, Vito is soon swayed by the lure of power and wealth that a life of Organized Crime can bring.

A petty criminal his whole life, Vito, along with his childhood friend, Joe, will descend into the world of Organized Crime. Together, they will work to prove themselves to the Mob as they try to make their names on the streets of a cold and unforgiving city.

Mafia 2 immerses players in the mob underworld of a fictitious late 1940's / early 1950's scenario. The game engages you in a cinematic Hollywood movie experience in a living, breathing city, fusing high octane gunplay with white knuckle driving and an engaging narrative.

reviewText:
Short version: 81%Mafia II has a really great episodic story structure and mostly avoids being just another GTA clone, but the cast and some of the questionable game design choices just cannot compete with its predecessor. Still, if you like mob stories, it is a very solid pick.

Long version:Mafia II is a decent GTA IV clone with emphasis on story and characters over the sandboxing elements. It follows the exploits of Vito Scaletta, the son of an immigrant to Empire Bay (New York), who, with his friend Joe, slowly finds his way into the Italian Mafia.

His tale is not a classic rise the power one, more like a series of schemes and jobs to raise money to pay back his latest debt. This creates a very realistic motivation but serves as a poor game element, because the developers regularly just wipe your entire in-game account to create a reason for the ‚Äúnext big plan‚Äù.

Since the plot follows a get rich, lose money cycle for almost an entire decade, it is very episodic in nature, divided into 15 chapters. The large time span and almost self-contained chapters were a good tool to build the world, but not so great when it came to character development. The cast does a great job, but when you see only a small glimpse of the characters‚Äô lives, even they cannot do too much. To compensate, all the missions feel unique with just few enough GTA-like shooting sprees to not turn it into another dumb TPS.

On its own, Mafia II is an enjoyable plot-oriented shooter/driver game with a small map (that feels more like a fan-made GTA IV mod project). Compared to its predecessor though, it feels shallow. Mafia 1 was like the Godfather trilogy with an excellent main character you could relate to: a good man who ended up in a bad life. Mafia II is more like a weaker season of Sopranos: grittier atmosphere, lots of cursing, and a main character that is nothing but a two-bit thug. It is a good game with a good story, but it had the misfortune to follow up a much better one.

This game was fun as hell. It was sort of like playing through an alternate earlier era version of Goodfellas. Certainly the dialogue was right in line with it as was the story.
The gameplay was pretty stellar. The cars handled fairly like real life cars, the gunfights were fun as hell, and the quests never really got boring. The story itself was engaging from beginning to end.
There were some laggy moments during some of the gunfights, but overall the game handled quite well, and considering the scope of the game, that was really pretty impressive. The choice of music was spot on.

This is one that somehow passed me by when it was released, but I was very glad to have had an opportunity to play it. There is actualy a lot of repllay value as far as collectibles and the potential to clear up missed quest variations, plau there is DLC (which I dont presently own) which I imagine ups the ante even more.

Just know....with Mafia gangster type people, there are no sunny endings, lol.

anyway, I give this one 8 out of 10. I also feel it is actually a must own must play. However, if you are overly sensitive and/opr dont understand the social dynamics of the 40's and 50's, you might give it a miss. You will likely be very offended by parts of this game. reviewText:
This game FAR exceeded my expectations. Great storyline, visuals, dialogue, and a decent combat system make this quite the experience.

I didnt like Mafia 1 much, but I figured I'd give this one a shot. It does away with all the excessive police fines and restrictions that the first game nagged about. You can still alert the police through speeding or hit-and-run incidents in this game, but now you can escape the police or choose to bribe them. The game appears to be open world and controls like a typical GTA game, but in actuality, its pretty linear. This isn't realy a bad thing. Its just something to keep in mind when playing. You wont have side quests or side missions to waste away time in the sandbox environment like you would in a typical GTA game. There are collectibles, but theyre all artwork and don't add any bonuses for your character.

Also, the game does a great job in connecting you to the main characters, which was the driving factor in me getting hooked.

The story takes shocking turns and by the time you finish the game, I'm sure you wont't regret spending your money on it.

Mario Puzo would be proud. 10/10.

reviewText: In an era when video games are moving away from relying on cinematics for storytelling, Mafia II draws on the rich mobster film history to weave a gripping drama about family, friendship, loyalty, betrayal, and pragmatism. If you're fond of quoting Don Corleone and Tony Soprano, don't miss this game.Mafia II is exactly the sequel Mafia fans have been waiting all these years for.It is ambitious in its presentation, the script immerses us in the life of a gangster from the very beginning, and the missions are hardly repetitive: there is always an unexpected twist or a new situation which tests our abilities.Yes, it's full of clich√©s, I saw them coming from a mile away, but it's exactly what you need to create that feeling of respect and even appreciation for what really were cruel murders, blood baths, territorial fights, extortion or drug traffic. But all of it elegantly done, in a tie and suit, in fancy restaurants and luxury cars.For fans of mobster movies, Mafia II is the ultimate toybox. It has period clothes, music, and architecture that perfectly evoke pre and post-war America, and a gritty script to boot.Mafia 2 is a great old-school-action game.

reviewText:
Cons: Short story.

Pros:
Graphics hold up six years later.
Engaging story, free of usual over-the-top antics of open world games.
Excellent voice acting.
Best open world atmosphere I've ever enjoyed.
Perfect vehicle handling.

If you haven't played this game, you should. If you're expecting GTA, forgetabouit. This is a movie set in an open world, where you can choose to take the long way home if you want. I've spent hundereds of hours on the Xbox 360 and plan to spend many more on PC, now that it's been added back onto Steam. The game really is a captivating experience that captures both the spirit of the 1940s, the 1950s, and the Mafia, rolling all three into a compelling story highlighted by well-written set-pieces and punctuated by some of the best voice acting put in a game. Graphically the game still shines, with PHYSX effects still stunning today. While the map is small compared to GTA V, it never feels small or cramped. Instead, each neighborhood has a specific feeling that includes arcitecture, pedestrian population and even the condition of the automobiles. Speaking of automobiles: no game has ever made driving so much fun in an open world. With normal steering/handling settings, the game has a very competent handling model that is both fun and approachable. With simulation settings and a controller for throttle/brake control, this becomes a driving simulation that rivals any other game. Cars have weight and handle like the beautiful barges they are. Graceful styling and recognizeable shapes make any fan of Automobiles from the 30s-50s feel right at home behind the wheel of a sport Smith Thunderbolt or an older Walter Coupe. Even with the Joe's Adventure and Jimmy DLC's, the game continues to amaze with some really nice set piece shootouts, surrounded by several extra hours worth of fun arcade-style open world missions which feel much closer to the form of GTA but without the sometimes over-the-top action sequences (you won't be landing a motorcycle on a train). Mafia II is my favorite game of all time because it takes me to a different time and place and let's me enjoy the life of Vito Scaletta. Buy it or somebody might break your legs.

This game is more of a journey, a journey into the life of Vito Scaletta, a criminal from the 1940-1950, that was caught during a robbery and had to choose between joining the army or being sent to prison, he chose the first option and he was sent to Sicily during WWII. On steam i didn't play this game very much, for some reason, when i tried to i kept having some visual glitches that annoyed me alot, tho i have played it non-steam a long time ago and everything worked like charm, they probably fixed the video issues.
What i didn't like from the publishers/developers, they kept teasing the gaming community with this game since 2007, that is not a nice thing to do.

All that being said, i recommend this game, it had a major emotional impact on me for various reasons, but mostly because of the similarities between Vito Scaletta and myself.
I am looking forward for Mafia III, if they decide to make it, and i really hope they will. This one was a blast.

reviewText:
Mafia II: The Movie.

The sequel to Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven, Mafia II is a third-person action-adventure game in the veins of GTA with a mafia theme instead and more story-focused set pieces. You take the role of Vito Scaletta, an up-and-coming gangster trying to climb through the ranks of the Mafia crime families.

This is without saying that Mafia II‚Äôs strongest aspect is its narrative. Whilst the story does not bring anything vastly new to the table, in terms of Italian gangster flicks, the way it unfolds from start to finish feels like a well written screenplay of a movie. It may not win any Oscars, but it is worthy of a nomination at the Golden Globes. Or maybe it is worth no awards, but a thing is certain, it is (subjectively) damn good. The characters are mature, sometimes even funny, but most importantly believable thanks to the strong dialogues and a sturdy voice acting performance from virtually every actor, making it a fairly immersive experience. It simply nails how a mafia should look, sound and act like.

On a presentation level, Mafia II is exceptional. With some really impressive visuals which even after five years still look great, its setting and atmosphere are incredibly beautiful and authentic, respectively. You feel like you are living in the ‚Äò40s-‚Äò50s America; from the way people behave to chilling to its brilliant soundtrack featuring plenty of classic tunes played on the radio back then. Not only that, but the physics in this game are reasonably realistic and sometimes even enjoyable to watch, whether that is debris falling off the walls from your bullets or the way your enemies ragdoll.

Gameplay-wise, it is self-explanatory as it plays out like any recent GTA game in an open-world with only main differences being the time period and the focus on dealing with the mafia gangs. It does have some really nice little touches such as the police chasing you for actually going over the speed limit. Mafia II, at times, really tries to aim for realism. The handling of the cars in the game is mostly acceptable although the controls for some cars could have been tuned a bit more. Surprisingly, the cover system implemented is fluent and functional as almost every wall or object can be used as a cover and there is not a moment where you feel the mechanic is broken in some form or another. However, the introduction of regenerative health might not please everyone as most of the time, from my experience, it feels like a cheap way to storm your way through gun shootouts. But the gunplay is solid as each shot you fire has certain punch to it.

Sadly, Mafia II has some obvious and rather irritating design flaws which are mainly due to the direction the developers decided to approach. In fact, these flaws did have a detrimental effect on my overall enjoyment of the game. You see, the biggest misstep the game takes is featuring a highly restricted, yet impressively detailed, open-world which most of the times can also feel ‚Äúempty‚Äù. Firstly, there are no side-quests to try out as you are limited to completing each chapter‚Äôs story mission (which is only one per chapter). They would have been a nice addition since they could have acted as a way to take a break from the main storyline. Next, there is basically not much else to do around town aside from using the only available shops which are the ones where you can buy cosmetic items such as clothes, acquire weapons and ammo from weapon vendors and garages to repair or mod your cars; and most of the times you do not even need them. Sure, you can go and rob the shops and get chased by the police, but that is as much fun as you can have from the game outside missions. Then you have the handful of scripted sequences where the game takes away your controls in the middle of whatever you are doing and have you waiting for each sequence to finish. In regards to this, there are moments in the story where the player is forced to do the most mundane activities which just are not fun - and off the top of my mind - like spending five minutes driving to a shop to buy new clothes in the middle of the mission only because you are told to do so. The lack of ways to complete the missions is also laughable since it is always a case of going from A to B in corridor-like patterns shooting your enemies or following your radar when driving your vehicle. All in all, Mafia II might be the most linear and restricted open-world game that I personally played to date, which honestly boggles my mind on why the developers even decided to feature an open-world if the game snatches most of your freedom. I do not even know if I should call it open-world as the only thing open about it is being able to drive around the whole map or shooting civilians when you are not in a story mission. Is it schizophrenic? In most aspects yes, as it appears to have an identity crisis on whether it wants to be a game or an interactive movie. Might as well watch the entire playthrough on YouTube since it plays out as a movie really well.

Other issues encountered are relatively minor, but I feel they are worth mentioning. For instance, the police AI can be silly at times as there are many occasions when they pathetically lose your track in their chase by simply increasing your vehicle‚Äôs acceleration, thus posing almost no challenge at all. The lower difficulties available are also extremely easy due to the regenerative health and the cover mechanics, making the experience less rewarding since all you have to do is taking cover to avoid any damage whatsoever. On the other hand, playing it on the hardest difficulty can be punishing at times since your health regeneration is slower and about three bullets can kill you. In a very story-driven game, you do not want to die frequently because it simply ruins the pace of the game. But more importantly, you do not want to die in a game featuring a shoddy checkpoint system. Mafia II‚Äôs checkpoint system can be poor at times as you can easily die, for whatever reason, closely to your next checkpoint (which you do not even know when and where it is) and forcing you to start all the way back from the last one saved which can be a bit farther back. Additionally, it would have been ideal if the enemy AI in general was more tactical in a way where they can rotate around their covers and make some sort of push in the battlefield as most of the times they just stand in the same position behind a cover, ultimately making themselves easy targets for the player who can swiftly move around covers. Lastly, the melee combat is pretty pointless. Once you learn the pattern of wait-dodge-punch, you can beat anyone without ever taking a hit.

Conclusively, Mafia II is a great interactive movie (masquerading as a game), but an average open-world game at best. However, its redeeming aspects are its strong narrative, authentic setting and atmosphere and the cast of interesting characters. Although I spent a lot more time discussing the negative aspects of the game that annoyed me, that is not to say I did not enjoy Mafia II for what it has to offer - just not fully. I only wish it were not so restricted in so many of its gameplay aspects. It is not a first person shooter, and even some of those have more freedom than Mafia II has. So it is a no brainer: if you are looking for a purely story-driven experience, Mafia II delivers it. Otherwise,  whichever copy of GTA you own should still provide you with plenty of hours of mindless fun. I do give some credit to Mafia II for not being a complete carbon copy of GTA though. Realistically, I would have given this a neutral score, but instead I recommend it mainly because I got it for free, as many others did, so I do not have any of that buyer‚Äôs remorse.

reviewText:
This game gets my seal of approval.

The game is simply amazing. The story is very good, the graphics, even for a 2011 game, are pretty damn good. The shooting mechanics are decent, the driving is OK (at least, on simulator mode).

However, this game has its downsides too. The open world feels empty and unfinished at some times. There is no free roam after finishing the story unless you buy the Jimmy's Vendetta or Joe's Adventures DLC or download a mod. And frankly, there aren't a lot of things to do other than playing the story.

TL;DR
If you're lloking for an open world game like GTA, don't buy this. However, if you want an amazing story (seriously, this is one of the best games I've ever played) then BUY THIS NOW.

reviewText:
Just a couple days ago I finally got around starting Mafia II which has been sitting in my backlog for a while now. Oh boy am I glad I did. It grabbed me from the start so that after only few days I have finished the campaign.

It's probably easy to compare this to Grand Theft Auto but both games are actually very different. In Mafia II there really is not much else besides the campaign. There are no side missions to speak of or even other forms of entertainment we are used to have in open-world games, races, mini-games etc. It does read as a disadvantage but in reality it is a big positive. The campaign is greatly paced and you always know what to do next. Wasting time with menial and most often unfun side occupations would hurt that pacing only and not add anything meaningful to the experience. What matters most is that I never felt the need that the game should have anything besides the campaign. The absent of a character leveling or mindless XP pop-ups is refreshing and fits great with the focused style of the game. Less is more here.
In terms of side activities you can count the collectibles probably. There are three. Playboy Magazines, Wanted Posters and Pinup Posters. Later is locked behind the Hard difficulty setting. The Wanted Posters are scrambled across the world and are a pain to collect. Collecting the Playboy Magazines is the easiest since they usually are strategically placed in the vicinity of campaign missions. These each unlock a single high resolution photo of an original playboy playmate of that period. Suffice to say it's NSFW (breasts). They appear only during certain missions and disappear later. Thankfully the devs did not opt to the stupid industry standard of making collectibles glow.

The world is done great. It's fairly big with distinct areas and aesthetics. Driving mechanics thankfully are great as well but you have to keep in mind that unlike GTA, most normal cars feel too slow and heavy. Once you get your hands on a sports-car, you will drive nothing but those.
Besides driving there is a focus on combat and I'm glad to say that shooting feels great. There is a nice cover mechanic and it just feels good to run into a firefight and slide seamlessly into cover. Enemy bullets do take away health-points very quick so you will have to use cover constantly. One thing I have to stress is the very great use of physics in combat. Glass shatters, wooden cover breaks apart nicely and even concrete walls break around the edges. It not only serves as beautiful eye candy but also adds a new mechanic and tactic to keep in mind during combat.
These two things, driving and shooting will be done plentiful and no matter how fun they are on their own, they would still become a chore if the story behind it faltered. It does not. On the contrary, the story is greatly written with great, believable characters. As someone who watched most popular gangster movies I was expecting many cliche events and lines to appear but to my surprise many events and turns I did not see coming. Without spoiling too much, you will be seeing the protagonist's rise in the mafia. The ending came abrupt. I was actually believing the story would continue but it  just stopped. So think, not playing throughout the whole life of a gangster but a slice of it. An early slice at that. It mostly revolves around you, Vito Scaletta and your best friend Joe Barbaro and how you both become gangsters in the mafia. Maybe it's the cliche I am used to from movies and games but I was positively surprised at Joe not being a boring and bland character.
Since there really is only the campaign to play, voice acting is important and for the most part it is really great. Leo's VO was exceptionally good. One voice stood out in a comical way. Vito's sister Francesca was bad. Really bad. The VO forced an usual high-pitched sound with her. No clue how that got OK'd.
The atmosphere of the 40s/50s America is hit nicely with old cars and music. Later comes from three radio stations. I'm not personally fond of the period's aesthetics and music but there are some catchy songs I'll listen to on Youtube for sure. The cars are an acquired taste. I don't find them appealing mostly but there's not much freedom with historic accuracy. Visually the game looks great. The city is greatly detailed with buildings and districts looking unique and fitting. Cars look great and the motion blur when driving fast is used to great effect. I also noticed that grass looks surprisingly good. Keeping in mind this is a ps360 era game, yes there are low-res textures and models but they mainly become only noticeable during close-up cutscenes.

Not all is perfect though. As I mentioned briefly, the campaign feels like there is something missing at the end. It ends faster than I'd imagined Vito's story to be. Not being able to roam the city freely after the ending only adds salt to the wound.
As said, the world is big with many places and buildings that stand out. Weirdly enough, most of these places went totally unused without any missions taking place there (dam, skyscrapers, water). Maybe it was planned initially but it got cut.
I think they also missed an opportunity with Vito's family. Her sister never gets much of a focus. A shame as it would have made for some nice arc to see her get polluted by her brother's money and power maybe.
I experienced some crashes which I could not solve but thankfully never lost too much progress. Some cutscenes are also pre-rendered movies with very low bitrates that really hurt their qualities. I have no idea why they didn't just make them run in-game in real-time (like other cutscenes), especially since the assets and everything basically in them are of in-game quality. Weird.

All in all though, I have to say I enjoyed my time with Mafia II immensely. The story, characters, atmosphere, combat all top-notch. It's a better game than GTAIV for sure even if it does not offer a similarly detailed world with many side activities but maybe because it is a very focused game that uses the open-world not only as a selling point but only as instrument for the campaign. I like this method better than GTAIV's bloated unfocused hodgepodge of menialities. Not even gonna compare story, writing and characters of the unbearable mess that GTAIV is with the greatness of Mafia II.
Mafia II is a great game and everyone should give it a try. It blew me away and will do for at least some others as well for sure. Now I am more interested in Mafia III than before. Hopefully they manage to bring over the strengths of Mafia II.

reviewText:
Welcome to a sandbox game that is not really a sandbox and prefers a more professional and mature approach than killing everyone in sight while spinning through the air in your tank like in Grand Theft Auto. Which is not necessarily a good thing, mind you, but most certainly something different from the usual. Even after completing the game you are not allowed to just freely wander around, unless you install a mod, but it has an open-world map none the less. Which has just about as much as nothing to explore, but still an open world! The game is apparently set in 40-50's, but if not for the cars and the music I would honestly just never know, because the city looks so oddly modern and there's not a lot of the atmosphere from that era in the game.

Still, though, you don't even have to explore the city, because you are mailny there for the story and story missions, which are, in my opinion, quite good. There's something quite satisfying about going to a shop, dressing into the best suit and coat with a fedora you could afford, grabbing your Thompson and driving to shoot some gangsters. It's good to play it in small bits, like two chapters at a time, like you would read a book.

It's basically a game about a young man climbing in the hierarchy of a mafia family and learning that being a Made Man" is a lot different from how he pictured it in his dreams. Also

reviewText:
If you are a gamer that enjoys proper storytelling and great stories and character backgrounds and development, then this is the game for you. If you enjoy running over hookers and roaming around, you might not enjoy this as much. I first played the pirated version right when it came out, and it is the only game that I have ever played in one sitting, not leaving the computer until I saw the end credits. I also recommend playing the original before this one as you'll miss out on some things.

Story: 9.5/10 :: Visual design: 9/10 Gameplay: 8/10 :: Difficulty: 4/10 :: Recommandation: Buy

:: STORY ::
As a big Mafia franchise fan, I might be a bit biased. However, I find the stories of both first and second game to be compelling and maybe, just maybe, two of the best stories in gaming history. I will not bother to compare the stories in the two games. It's pointless to me, as I did not except a remake of the original, so the fact that the second game's story was different and even intertwining with the first game's story was more than enough.

Unlike the first game, the focus of the story is around only two characters Vito and Joe, and their quest to becoming financially successful by unlawful or questionable methods. The relationship and chemistry between the two characters is what matters, and the fact that, no matter what difficulties you may encounter along your paths, you two will have each other's backs.

The side characters are also interesting, and the one who I found most interesting was Henry, one of the made men who you end up working for and working with, who later turns out to be an informant for the FBI. This is one of the characters that deserved a DLC along Joe and I hope we'll be seeing him in future games.

I have seen and read many complaints regarding the ending. However, I do not feel the same way. The uncertainty of the ending seemed justified and much more bleak than the one in the first game, where it shows you how the events will turn out. Not only does it leave room for your imagination to kick in and choose your own ending, but it also leaves room for future installments to link to events that are still unclear.  I am referring here, obviously, to the fact that, you do not know if Vito did something to save Joe or not.

The story can keep you playing just by itself, and without a doubt it will keep me coming back to replay the game, just like I did and still do so very often with the original.

:: VISUAL DESIGN ::
The location where the game takes place is visually impressive and diverse. It captures the feel of the era with great fidelity, and the grim, sad aspect of the city in full winter is a vivid representation of the World War II period in the states. Unlike the first game, the entire city is open for exploring since the first minute you gain control and a set of lockpicks.

The character designs are very well put together, with few exceptions. However, you can tell the difference between main or recurring characters and episodic ones. The recurring cast has much more effort put in detailing their appearance, expressions and eye movements.

Vehicle design is, just like in the first game, a strong point. It's not your regular open-world driving simulator. The cars have responsiveness according to the era and the state of the car, not to mention, just like the first game, progressing the story and in time gives you access to newer and better cars, with a wide variety to choose from.

:: GAMEPLAY ::
I would like to praise this game in terms of gameplay, however there are aspects of it that clearly bugged the hell out of me.

Car NPCs are one big steaming pile of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. I have no idea where they learned how to drive. Their collision detection is way off. If you steer to avoid them, they will just steer towards you. If they notice you in the way, they accelerate. If they come in an intersection, without traffic lights, they won't give right of way. If you stop to avoid them and they stop as well (usually in corners), they'll start driving right away. If they change lanes, they won't check if somebody is coming on the other lane, they'll just change it right in you.

Police NPCs are again a big issue. Cars bumping into me, I get fined. Police cars bumping into me. I get fined. Level 4 police chase? Easy as pie to escape.

The pros of the gameplay are the variety of activities you can do in game to get immersed in the universe. Buy clothes (tho' very limited options), get drinks, get food, go to car shops, gun shops, get gas for your car (if you'll go for achievements, you'll need it), upgrade your rides. For a 6 year old game, these are very good features. I hope that fore the future we'll get more of these little" aspects.

Also

reviewText: The vintage mafia, go on- read to find out about Vito and his life in Empire Bay. You can't forget the view of this city. Empire Bay is a fictional city on the East Coast of the United States of America, based on a combination of New York City, Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Detroit with elements from other US cities during the '40s and '50s, that serves as the setting for Mafia II. It features a completely open-ended map of about 4 square miles. The city also features sights based on famous landmarks such as the Brooklyn Bridge and the Empire State Building. And that's only the city! Well there's a lot to tell about main character- Vito Scaletta. Vito is the strong, smart, silent type, the opposite of his best friend Joe, who is much more flamboyant and loud. This quality is admired by his many bosses. He has seemingly strong morals, and doesn't kill because he wants to, but because he knows he has to. Vito doesn't aspire to be the Don, he just wants a bit of money and a bit of respect so that he can help his family out. Vito seems to really care about those who have helped him out but when he is released from prison, he seems to get colder. For Corporal Scaletta's bravery and participation in Operation: Husky - he recieved the Distinguished Service Cross (DSC for short) and for being injured in the service of the United States Military - he received the Purple Heart. One of the medals was handed over by General Patton himself. Although it is never mentioned, he received the World War II Victory Medal which all U.S. combatants of the war received following the victory, as well as the European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal which was awarded to all U.S. combatants in the European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign of World War II.\nWell, you'll ask me: About what is this game? Well, the storyline for Mafia II is a gritty drama and chronicles the rise of Vito Scaletta, the son of Sicilian immigrants. As the game progresses, Vito joins the Falcone crime family and becomes a made man" along with his best friend Joe Barbaro. What happens next? Buy this game and find out!\nTo be honest

reviewText:
Play as an Italian-american man in the 1950's with a quest to find all the playboy magazines and beat up all the paper sellers. Great shooting, Great movement, Great characters and voice-acting, superb.

This game really bring me back to the 1950's or atleast makes me wish I lived in the 1950's, truly a great era with magnificent music, cars, clothing and bribable cops, aslong as you don't kill anyone ;)

The only downside gameplay wise is that there are no freeroam after you finish the game which when you play it you quickly see the fun of just screwing around in Old New York with the great physics and gameplay.

And then there's the dlc's. The only dlc's worth buying if you have some loose change is the car/clothing packs but the the extra story dlc's is an awfull attempt from 2K to make an extra buck, they didn't take their time to voice act or make cutscenes, all the mission info you get is from a little box on the screen and you get arrows telling you where to go and a timer to try to do it as fast as possible. Spare your money don't buy the story dlc's.

Overall Mafia II is an absolutely great game and very much worth the money, just don't buy the story dlc's and do some freeroam between missions and have fun !

Developers!!!

reviewText:
Presentation
There's always been a huge audience for anything related to the Mafia, but with an increasing number of people looking out for such things, we've seen more than a few unneeded spin-offs to what an Italian Mafia story was meant to be; luckily Mafia II returns to the roots of that concept, just like the game before it, concentrating once again on making a name for yourself in a corrupt world. The takes place in the fictional city of Empire Bay, inspired by the look of major U.S cities like New York and Chicago during the 50's, including some of the major landmarks from the real world and combining them with a unique map design that makes Empire Bay feel like a real place in space and time. The map here is enormous and with that comes the main problem while you're out exploring it as it feels empty for most parts, and to be honest during the story there are lots of well-made locations that you'll probably never visit unless you're just into exploring without actually doing missions or challenges. The lack of side missions or challenges is clearly felt in this one, and that has nothing to do with the story being organized in chapters whatsoever, but it feels disappointing that even after you're done with the amazing story there is nothing else to keep you roaming on the streets of Empire Bay. On the brighter side, this is probably one of the best stories you've seen in years, and 2K does a great job introducing you into the world controlled by the Mafia in the late 40's all up to the 50's. Everything about the atmosphere of that time period seems right and this is one of those stories that will probably remain in your mind for a very long time. You play as Vito Scaletta, a veteran finding himself back into Empire Bay after suffering an injury during the war and being sent back home for a while, time which extends permanently once he gets in touch with some old friends. The menus are easy to browse and the loading screens will get by you pretty fast; in addition to that you can view all your collectibles in the game from the main menu. The characters are well-made and have personality in every single aspect, although having the ability to change certain decisions would've been nice, adding to the replay value, but the story is awesome enough to be worth your time as it is.
Rating: 7.5

Gameplay
There's not a lot of diversity in gameplay here as you'll probably spend most of your time in cover, trying to aim a headshot towards an enemy who is also hiding in cover or getting him while he's advancing for another place of cover. There is nothing wrong with that as the game is fun to play and the controls work well in that environment, but don't expect to rush into a group of enemies without strategy and succeed, because it probably won't happen. There are a few moments in the story where the basic cover shoot-out will be replaced by activities like lockpicking cars, throwing molotovs and so on, but those are few and easy to forget. On the bright side, the range of weapons that you have at your disposal and new ones that will constantly keep showing up as you advance the story forward will keep making things more interesting, starting from basic things like pistols and later moving on to epic mafia weaponry such as the Tommy Gun. Even with the shooting mechanic as basic as it is, the environment in which it takes place changes the strategy every time, as lesser cover spots will require you to stay longer in one place and snipe out everyone in your range, while plenty of cover will give you the opportunity to move more freely and surprise your enemies from behind. Driving around the town is fun and there are plenty of cars to try out and upgrade to make your collection bigger, but unfortunately those services are only meant to provide a few minutes of extra fun after you've completed the main story as you'll probably ignore those features at all the first time you play through the campaign since you will be too preoccupied following the story, and since there are no additional missions apart from those following the main plot, there is little reason to take a break from the story. The thing that will keep you going in this game is the motivation to see how the story unfolds, and even if there's nothing much else to do after completing the story, robbing stores, evading cops and challenging achievements will keep you going for a while.
Rating: 8

Graphics
The landscape of Empire Bay looks amazing, leaving you drooling over the beautifully detailed buildings and admiring just how authentic everything looks, despite areas being so empty due to the lack of side missions or challenges. There is detail to everything you'll find in the city: the cars look as they did in the 50's, the city features old landmarks like The Brooklyn Bridge or The Empire State Building combined with other digitally created locations that make the city feel alive. The main characters certainly look like they're out of the 50's and the one thing this games does best is to keep you attached to them. Throughout your playthrough you'll encounter lots of different characters from different families in the Mafia, each one being unique and keeping you interested in their personal stories as well as their own part in the main story that the game wants to tell. Unfortunately this realism of characters will often be interrupted by bad facial animations and even worse lip syncing.
Rating: 8

Audio
The voice acting is well done, having Italian accents specific to the time period and the birthplace of the characters, and combined with the amazing dialogue and the lines that never get old, including Mafia classics, the experience doesn't get any better than this. The soundtrack is amazing including hit tracks from the 50's divided into 3 radio stations that you can change whenever you want while in the car. The use of certain tracks during mission makes the sadness of someone getting shot feel authentic and make you experience what being a gangster really felt like. With very few exceptions, the sound effects are a blast for the ear and a pleasure to hear over and over again, especially those classic Tommy Gun shots that you're already familiar with from Mafia movies.
Rating: 9.5

Extras
There are lots of collectibles in the game, some which you'll have to find across the city and others awarded for completing a mission on a certain difficulty level. If you're hunting for achievements or simply want to see all the playboys, this will keep you occupied for a while, however the lack of multiplayer or leaderboards for missions is felt, and after collecting everything it will take you a while to jump into the story all over again. The difficulty levels on the other side are well done and it's a good addition if you want to replay the story on a higher difficulty level.
Rating: 7.5

Verdict
This is an amazing experience if you like killing people and Mafia related stuff; too bad the game does suffer from the lack of extra content to keep you engaged into the game even after completing the story. If you are looking for a brilliant story this is a must buy no doubt, and with the price being lowered since its release it's probably worth your bucks.
Rating Overall: 8.1

reviewText:
Almost a perfect game but ultimately falls short because of a few glaring issues.

Mafia 2 has the best atmosphere of any game I have played. You play as a gangster in the 1940s-1950s and you feel like you are in the world. Everything about the cars, buildings, stores, and even the radio convinces you that you really are in that city. When you drive around and hear about the remote control being invented or see more powerful and modern cars as time progresses. The attention to detail is very nice with the speedometer being time correct, the radio tuning in on actual music from that era, and the cars being ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to handle and not going very fast. I have a HD 4000 and I can only run the game on the lowest settings but it still looks good enough to soak in the atmosphere

The story of the game revolves the typical mafia story of a guy who started from the bottom" and grew his way up until he did something that made him realize that crime never plays. Its clich√© but it‚Äôs a very good story here. The characters in this game feel real with you feel emotionally invested in your character hoping they make the choices you do.

The mechanics are OK with standard 3rd person shooter stuff. The game relies a lot on realism so you die faster. There is regenerating health but each time it recovers to a lower degree. There are stealth mechanics but you utilize them in maybe 2-3 missions depending on how you count them so they are kind of worthless. You get cool time period weapons with the classic Tommy being the weapon you rely on the most. You almost never have to buy any because you just pick them off the dead guys in missions with shooting. You have to use cover in the game and it feels fluid except when you want to go into covers along walls because Vito can‚Äôt figure out which wall (of a corner) to stick to.

A MAJOR issue with the game is that the sandbox is a lie (sort of). There is a large map where you can go and explore but 1) there isn‚Äôt anything to do and 2) there is no free roam. Normally

reviewText:
So before I get into this, it should be noted that Mafia II is no longer available on the Steam Store as I write this, if you already own the game you can install and play it, but if you don't, you're going to have to wait for a bit, it should be noted that Mafia II just turned 5 the day of its takedown, because the game uses licensed music tracks in the in-game radio stations, it's possible that the digital takedown is a direct result of this.

Buttttt to the review of the game, starting with the backstory:

Mafia II is a Third-Person shooter where the player takes control of Vito Scalleta, an Italian-American who immigrated to Empire Bay, United States from Sicily, Kingdom of Italy in 1931, Vito being born in 1925, Vito's family is thrown into debt and economic difficulty, the great depression hitting them hard, eventually Vito and childhood friend Joe Barbaro form a close relationship in their teenage years, Vito's father drowns in the docks he works at so Joe and Vito have to turn to a life of crime to make ends meet.

After Vito is arrested for attempted robbery in 1943, he is given two choices: Jail, or fight for the US army in Operation Husky, the allied invasion of Sicily, Vito being fluent in Italian and Sicilian as well as English. It is here when the player takes control of Vito, as he and his band of US marines help liberate a smal Sicilian town, San Celeste, from Fascist Blackshirts loyal to Benito Mussolini, Vito is eventually injured later during the war and is temporarily discharged after being healed up, but is due to return to the front in a few months, after meeting up with his family, and finding out his younger sister still has to pay back debts of their father, Vito also meets up with Joe, who finds a way to get Vito fake papers to get him out of service. Vito, wanting to pay back his father's debt, decides that honest labor won't cut it, so he turns to the Mafia families in Empire Bay to get him enough cash to pay his late father's debt.

The game is great, a great plot with great characters, voice actors, music selection, and dialogue, Mafia 2, even if it can be beaten quickly, provides for hours of content and excellent gameplay, however, there are some things you should know about it:

This game, while being an open world game, doesn't have a free roam" mode (however there are mods that add this)
