This game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing great. The sequel to the original Mafia, taking place in the classic NYC. There's a lot to say about this game.

+This game has an AMAZING ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing story, even though its linear. It's very in-character with the mafia theme. The writing is great and you'll find yourself wanting to move on to every next chapter to see what happens next.
+The characters are very developed and memorable. Vito, Joe, Marty, and Leo will especially never escape my mind when I return to think of this game.
+The dialogues are very realistic, entertaining, and well-written. Wheras most games have this nonsense where only one person is ever audible at one time, you'll be having conversations while some guy is screaming in the background or a drunk friend is singing random nonsense. It's just amazing.
+The city is fairly big and great fun to explore, with no real loading screens, but there are some second-long transitions between larger buildings and the city.
+The graphics are still great even for today's standards. The lights of the cars, the ground after the rain, the view in the distance in daylight. The character models are fantastically done.
+The sounds are phenomenal. Every aspect of them. From the cars on the streets to inside of tunnel systems. From gunshots in a building to outside. They are realistically done and a pleasure to listen to.
+The cards feel right. If I'm driving a truck, it's not as easy to control as a sports vehicle. If I'm driving a sports vehicle, I can hit amazing speeds. You can even upgrade and customize your car, keeping 10 vehicles of your choice in your garage to be accessed at any time.
+The combat is great. This is a third person cover based shooter at its core. Cover works realistically and the guns play quite nicely, you even have a nice selection of guns to pick from.
+The AI combat performs strategically in most situations and friendly AI are not useless in combat, they actually contribute, hell they could win for you on the easier difficulties.
+-The radio stations are great and play classic songs from the eras of '45 and '51, however they seem quite limited. You'll be hearing the same era-based songs across the entire game on the same 3 radio stations.
+-Due to the linearity of the game, you don't get to enjoy the open world of this game as much as you would in other games like Saints Row, but in my opinion that was a good thing for the way this game works, yet some may take it badly.
-The AI do NOT know how to drive. They seem to just wish you didn't exist. The moment a light turns green you're being honked at. If you try to go straight, the jackass on the other end making a left turn suddenly thinks he has the right of way and will honk and scream at you. If you're cruising through a green light at high speeds, that jackass also doesn't think you exist, because he gladly swerves right into you, only to get out of his car and blame you for it. The AI drivers were easily the WORST part of this game and the largest irritant of it as well.
-Pedestrians on the street would stand on walkways staring at your car refusing to let you get by, and even walk in front of it when you honk the horn at them when you're oncoming.
-Most cars and pedestrians actually ignore your horn flat out. But they sure know how to use their horns on you.
-The way the law" in this game works is stupid. Speed? Get a ticket. Give a cop an accidental love tap? You're under arrest. Run a red light? Drive in the wrong lane? Do donuts in an intersection? Crash into another car? Cops don't give a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. BUT DON HELP YOU

This game gets a 9/10 without a doubt. This is a game you can't afford to pass on. This is one you HAVE to experience."

reviewText:
Finally glad this is back up on Steam.
Played a PS3 version for dozens of hours. Bought it here just to support the devs and test the PC port (which holds up).
Short review: Mafia II isn't a great example of an open-world game. Well it certainly feels like a believable city with diverse locations and different districts, and wonderful radio, and decent lore, there's barely anything to do. This is probably ought to all the cut content. There's nothing outside of the main story, just nothing sadly.

The reason this comes recommended is ought to the story. Christ, this is probably one of the better crime related stories in video games. While the plot is simple, the character interactions and voice acting in this game just sell it. We have believable goals, a friendship that has some incredible writing behind it, and the game gives characters enough time that we may feel some sort of emotional tie to them. That being said, it occasionally drops the ball, but it was mostly a well-written story.

The gunplay and driving tight, even if one is using a controller. The AI isn't particularly advanced, but the game steadily raises its challenge which keeps the gunplay engaging. The driving just has enough depth that there's some sort of skill involved.

Overall, this is a game to play almost entirely for the story. Well the world is engaging while one is in the main story, don't expect much outside of it.

reviewText:
Mafia II is pretty fun ‚Äì at first everyone wants to compare it to GTA IV but it really is very different.  Unfortunately its no where near as good.  But fans of Mafia movies (who isn't) should enjoy the game and its often on sale for a good price.  Its a good 3rd person action shooter.

Pros:
-Graphics are reasonable, albeit a bit aged.
-Controls, movement, and aim all work well.
-Will keep you occupied for 10-15 hours.
-Car driving sim mode is actually fun; unfortunately it makes the game much too hard.  Car driving is much better than it ever was in GTA IV.
-Cars are somewhat upgradeable and can be stored in your garage

Cons:
-Story is kinda laughable, not very well done IMO.  The stories in other games are MUCH better.
-Its not really an open world in the way that GTA IV is.  You can drive wherever you want but the story is actually VERY linear.
-The cars can be very slow, although this is realistic for the time its not very fun.
-The city is huge and there is no quick transport option, so you will spend a lot of time slowly driving around.
-The police' AI is horrible.  If you hit someone (or they hit you) any nearby cops immediately want to fine you for a hit and run; even if you get straight out of the car.
-Cut scenes always show you with a 1911 even if you have been using a Thompson for the last 20 minutes
-The M1 Garand is very underpwoered.  One shot center mass should take enemies down.
-You can save cars in your garage but they are often lost or deleted in the course of a mission.

reviewText:
PLEASE NOTE: I was playing this game on a laptop with Intel Celeron Quad Core at 1.7ghz, and idk if it has a graphics card, though i believe it‚Äôs an intel HD one. Either way, my point is i was by no means on high graphics, and often i encountered lag. This does not affect the storyline, but it does affect the gameplay, so this review will be based MOSTLY on MY experience of the game. Please enjoy.

Indeed not the most popular game ever, and it doesn't compare to games like GTA or COD. Mafia 2 will take you through a story, in the shoes of an Italian by the name of Vito Scaletta. Starting out as a teenager who commits mild crimes, you are captured and used in the army for the invasion of Sicily, as you speak the language. You are heavily outnumbered and outgunned, but you hold off the enemy force long enough before someone to come to your rescue. Having served your time in the army you come back to the streets in a hope to lead what you could call a life, but naturally, life bites back. His family are in debt, he needs to earn money for himself too, and due to the fact he doesn‚Äôt know what to do, he runs to his oldest mate, Joe, and starts a life of crime.

I tried not to give too much away there for the purpose of spoilers, but in this review i endeavour to cover at least enough of the game to either make you hit purchase or cancel.

So, where do i start?

Storyline:
This game has a brilliant story line, and it is one that you will really enjoy playing. The idea of playing as one person through his life is something rarely seen in games today, it's normally just a character that you decide to kill people as. There are highs and lows in Vito's Life, and some moments are quite emotional, but it is not the story line that makes the game, but it is indeed a good foundation. i do not want to give too much away, but if you are sensitive to spoilers, do not read any further than the end of this sentence, but skip to the next paragraph. The storyline is very powerful, and while i was playing it i could not help but feel for Vito, especially due to his bad childhood. He sets out as a very poorly educated man, the only thing he knows how to do is kill, and he needs a job. The story creates some nice side-missions, and you really feel the desperation and pressure that Vito is living in. He is naive, and stupid, and lunges at the first chance he gets to earn megga bucks. Morally 'right' and 'wrong' never came into it. 0It is definitely more fun to play the path that Vito took, than a more peaceful one, which will be why the designers did it, but at the same time it is very repetitive, and this is what annoys me. You start killing people in the army, then you do it for cash, then for the Mafia. Each shootout is very different, but in another way they are almost identical. Weapon choices are not very good, the most interesting come off the people you have killed. Gunfights are not as satisfying as i would like, and it is really annoying when you kill a load of enemies, and loads more randomly appear. The worst scene i found for that was the last one, before the end of the game. That leads me on nicely, the end of the game.....what a disappointment. When the game finishes there is not really much to do, due to the fact it was a story, when the story ends...it is over. There is no option to free-roam, but if you read on in the review i will tell you why that is probably a good thing. You can but a DLC named Jimmy's Vendetta, where you get to play as another guy, and it does offer more free roam Later i will talk about the DLC's, as i have them all, and the difference they really make to the game. If you enjoy just screeching tires and shooting, this will be a game that requires thought, as it offers both, but i believe it is too unbalanced.

I rate the story 9/10 for its creativity and sheer emotional impact. I was quite sad when i'd finished it, but at the same time i was glad because it had taken so long and at times been quite boring.

Sounds:

Well, there are a lot of these. Good voice acting does make this game very enjoyable to listen to, but maybe that was it, it should have been listened to. People do swear, especially in combat, which is nice really, because all Total War games have little speech at all, and no swearing. I was taken back really by the quality of sounds in this game, and they really add to the atmosphere of the scene, making it very enjoyable. I can't remember if there were things like birds and wind that you could hear, but nonetheless i think the sound is to a good quality. I also like the touch of the radios in the cars, and they play authentic (‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) songs. I only ever found about 2 that i liked. Dreeeeeeeem.......dreem dreeem dreeem.... that one was catchy. (Spelling dream was wrong on purpose for those that care, that is how it sounds in the song). Anyway, back on track. Main characters in the game all sound different, making it feel more real, as in some games like Total War, they all sound the same. The civilians have got a sense of humour, they ask you thinks like 'Are you a pedo?' etc. if you 'invade their personal space. I do not really know why, but i think they are funny.

Overall, 8/10 for the sound, everything considered, the engines are a bit annoying over the radio.

Graphics:
Awesome. Blood sprays off people when they are shot or punched, and pools of blood lie on the floor next to them. Snow looks really realistic, as does grass. Really the graphics make the game what it was, even down to the cut scenes. There were parts that looked a bit cheap, but it was still believable, and that‚Äôs what you have to do to play Mafia 2, believe, because none of it is true. I cant think of a lot to say about the graphics, from dust to textures on houses, by my standards its all there.

Gameplay:

Well, shooting it satisfying, though gets boring for the long extents of time you end up doing it. Mafia 2 includes 2 moves everywhere you go, there is a good/Peaceful move, or a bad/violent one. The whole game works around this basis, and though the choice is limited, it works well. O n a good, fast computer I find that shooting it all too easy, a bit too light, same with fist fighting, and rarely is the desperation there to kill the enemy and leave. It is always something you seem to enjoy, but get too much of, and because you enjoy it, it loses realism. You follow a story as I said before, and in the time between missions all you can really do is yet again‚Ä¶more shooting. You can steal cars, but getting the money to upgrade them is impossible unless you do the next mission, or scene in the story. It is annoying how things would go wrong all the time, and in some cases would never be put right. The gameplay is basic, and sometimes there is a long boring, and un necessary drive from one end of the map to the other. Despite a lot of time and care being put into the city, I don‚Äôt need to see it again and again every 5 seconds of my life. Most missions are very similar, and towards the end of your journey you just do the missions as a job, and you get to the point where you just want to see the next cut scene. In all fairness, that was the best part of the game, and I think with some good actors, it would have made a better movie.

Overall I rate the game 7/10. The quality of it is generally good, but you really wish there was a fast forward button for all the wasted driving, and more to do in the free roam world. Vito never gets Hungry, so really you never NEED to eat, until you are injured. Personally I liked the game, a lot, but even with the DLC which provides a more ‚Äòfree roam‚Äô experience, there is little to do, consequently I have no desire to play it again for a while. It‚Äôs like watching the same film 10 times in a row, it‚Äôs just BORING.

I hope you enjoyed this review, or at least I hope it helped. Thanks for reading, and Bye for now ;D

reviewText:
Longer/prose review below

Pros:
-Combat is great
-One of the best stories I've played in a game
-Soundtrack
-Driving is fun
-Amazing world building

Cons:
-Short (10 hours on max difficulty to beat story; no side missions)
-Awful checkpointing system

Personal issues:
-Can't shoot from cover without exposing yourself
-No shooting from cars
-Wanted system is annoying
-Enemy cheapshots and difficulty spikes (bad checkpoints don't help this)

Mafia 2 is a great game with an excellent story, good combat system and amazing driving but it's not for everybody.  The story, whilst excellent is fairly short; I beat the game in about 10 hours at the hardest difficulty setting. If you don't enjoy cutscenes or slow moments, this game isn't for you. For example, the game has a section where you have to clean a toilet; you're forced to do this as an unskippable event which adds to the emersion but it's certainly not fun. The game also tries to be emmersive as there is a lack of fast travel which does get tiresome after some time, especially if you die in a crash and get sent back across the map.
The game tries to add in some realism as your car needs fueling after a while and if you crash too hard, you need to get out and repair it. You can only take about 3 bullets (on hard mode) so most of your time in combat will be spent waiting in cover for enemies to pop up at you. The combat is fun but it feels like whack-a-mole at times.
The checkpointing is what ruins the experience for me. One mission tasks you with going through a building to find one guy - the mission is about 20 minutes long and there are about 4 checkpoints with cheapshots everywhere and a cross map drive. This is probably my biggest gripe and lost this game a point /10.
Soundtrack fits the time period well, songs are not to everybody's taste but will appeal if you're in to older music or jazz and blues.

Buy it on sale - it's a good game but too short for ¬£20. 8.5/10

reviewText:
To start with, let me just say I have never actually played the first Mafia but after seeing this game, I would definetly give it a try. Now mafia 2 provides an awesome combination of combat, action and storyline, all of which a gamer would even become emotionally attached too. You are Vitro Scaletta an italian immigrant coming to the USA with the rest of your family in order to chase the American dream, until you find there is none. Mafia 2 fully emerses you as a gamer into the world of 1940-50s. If anything it reminds me of a combination between the Godfather, Goodfellas and Scarface, all of which are AAA titles.

The AI within this game are intelligent compared to other games, they know when to move and contain interactive features with the gamer. The driving mechanics are also one you'd hate so much you love it. It provides a feel of as to how cars behaved back then featuring heavy steering and long rev changes, for advanced users it also provides a simulation mode in which would take time to master, but for me... I'd prefer the normal driving. ;)

This game does not at all lack action, driving or a unfufilling storyline, to sum it all up in one sentence, one of my all time favorites.

reviewText:
One of the best Games I have played in a long time. It has been a while since I last played this game however I did play it at least 3 times on the PS3 and about 40hrs on PC(with a terrible setup).

This game for me at least puts alot of pressure on GTA to perform. The physics of the game make me feel like im in the 1940s and 50s. The cars dynamics are superb and since the first MAFIA I have always thought they were far superior to GTA.

This game has done so much with a small team.
- AWESOME Story. I felt worried for the two main characters, I wanted them to win at all times. With a game that focuses  mainly on its story to reel gamers in this one does NOT dissapoint. It gets an A in my book. Only reason why it isn't a A+ is just because its predictable. You can kind of tell whats going to happen next. Even so, it still manages to surprise you once in a while and deliver an experience that will keep you coming back for more and more.
-The game physics are some of the best of any video game I have ever played. While its not need for speed status for vehicle or battle field for character controls and firefights, this game managed to get the feel just right. Since I started playing, to the point where started re-playing this game almost immediately is a pleasant experience going trough the game. The weapons feel good to weild and at no point was I ever bored or annoyed by the controls.
- The city. With a huge map and so many roads to drive on I was a little dissapointed in this title, however not upset. The only quarral I had with it is that to me the first Mafia felt more real some how(perhaps because it was the first, perhaps its because thats when I fell in love with the title) All in all the city is rather dead, there aren't too many NPCs and when you do see them, they arent really that interesting to look at. They just go on their own business like you arent a homocidal crazed mafia hit man running around their city.
Over all the game play is TONS of fun, the missions are quite entertaining, and the story it self makes you care for the main characters. Its deep, and rich with plot twists and ofcourse this is mafia so quite alot of brutality.

For me this game is definitely a MUST OWN. I found my self going back to replay missions at the hardest setting and trying out different things whenever possible. If you were ever doubtfull, stop, and pick this game up. At the time of this review its 30 bucks and a bunch more DLCs. I personally hate that we have to pay for DLCs, I believe games are already over priced but thats just me. You'll go trough the main story line and will definitely want more.

reviewText: Mafia II, well it was a long time coming. The developers wanted to take a lot of time to make this game right. The original Mafia was one of my favorite games of all time. Top 10. Mafia II features excellent graphical fidelity, sound design (amazing contemporary music) Immersive voice acting and pretty damn good shooting and general gameplay.\n\nThink of it as a more serious Grand Theft Auto title, with a better story and more realistic gameplay. To be honest if you like Grand theft Auto, or a 3rd person open world this game is going to be a win for you. If you want to messa round with 30-60s cars and weapons, and enjoying a stroll through that time periods lively streets then Mafia II is going to be a win for you. The shooting feels great, very responsive and snappy. The weapons are fun, the driving is good and the world is rich. Its a solid title I can honestly say if you are a fan of the genre you cannot go wrong with Mafia II.

reviewText:
Mafia 2 is a good game that could have been amazing.

There is a lot of good, a lot of inexplicably bad, and a lot of wasted potential.
First, the story. It's decent, but there's rarely anything going on, and when there is, it's either near the end or doesn't last very long.
A lot of events have no impact on the story whatsoever, and most characters are pretty bland, particularly the main protagonist, whose only personality trait is his complete lack of care for his actions, he just does whatever he's told until the final missions, and most of what he does before getting into the mafia is just busy work.

Busy work you'll have the privilege to experience for yourself.

This leads me to my next point : the gameplay.
First of all, the missions. Some of them are, as I said earlier, busy work. You drive a cigarettes truck for a bit, park it, give cigarettes to people, go somewhere else, and do it again. Sure, after that you'll get to shoot some greaseballs in the face for burning your truck down, but the first half of this mission is terrible, and stuff like that happens pretty often.

Another problem with mission design is that the game forces you to drive everywhere. And I mean everywhere. Drive to Carlo's, watch a cutscene, drive to get someone, and then drive to the mission zone. When the mission is done, drive back to your place. This is really annoying, despite the game's fantastic physics. Driving is fun, but being forced to drive accross the map quickly turns driving into a tedious task.

Checkpoints are very scarce, but missions are short so this really isn't a problem, except in the DLC, where you have to start all over again (including the lenghty driving sessions) if you fail.

Despite their lazy checkpoints, DLC missions actually fix a lot of the game's issues, and most of them involve you shooting bad guys. A lot of them. The car stealing missions in Jimmy's vendetta can get a bit boring at times, but it makes up for it by having a lot of shootouts, most of which are surprisingly well designed.

Now, one of my favourite aspects of the game. The marvellous physics engine! It makes driving incredibly weighty and fun, and makes shootouts really intense. Wooden crates get torn apart and send wood flying everywhere, bottles explode, glass shatters, lights go out, bullets leave giant holes  in conrete walls and send dust flying everywhere.

Weirdly enough, you can't shoot from your car. Some might see it as a big problem, but the game doesn't need it. Besides, it makes car chases more challenging.

The APEX physics option doesn't seem to do a huge lot, but is completely brokens and halves the framerate of the game (your mileage may vary).

Finally, the best part of the whole game, the gunplay. The game lets you carry a metric ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ton of guns, and they're all very fun to use. They sound good, they look good, and they feel good. The recoil is very nicely done, and makes automatic weapons particularly fun to use.

The game uses health regen and a cover system. But have no fear! They don't impact the game in any negative way (which is a miracle). Your health only regenerates to about 75% and you'll need food to replenish it. The cover system is extremely basic and only useful to get you out of spicy situations when you're about to die. The game actually lets you run around the place and shoot people without forcing you to hide behind a wall, and doesn't even force you to zoom in (!) to be accurate at medium range!

Mafia 2's big problem is that you don't get gunfights as often as you'd want. Some missions even rely entirely on you using your fists, and the melee combat system is really bad. It's basically impossible to lose as long as you're holding your block key.

Another very good aspect of Mafia 2 is the atmosphere. The cars look fantastic, and so does Empire bay. It's colorful, it's flashy, and the radio is amazing. All the characters naturally have a cheesy mafioso accent, which may or may not be great, depending who you ask. (it's great)
It's nice to have a shooter that doesn't look completely dull.
Despite its open world, Mafia 2 doesn't have anything for you to do in it outside of the storyline.
It serves as a beautiful backdrop, and driving in the streets while dodging traffic at 100km/h is fun, but secondary missions would have been welcome. The cops don't do a whole lot, but will come after you if you exceed the speed limit or bump into another car. They can get mean if you start to shoot at them, and they won't hesitate to pull out the tommy guns.
The game's wasted potential comes in the lack of secondary missions, which could have easily fixed some of the game's biggest problems by adding more gunfights and introduce car races (it's a shame they didn't implement any, because the car physics are some of the best around, and tuning your car isn't very useful).

To sum it up, Mafia 2 is a good game despite its flaws. Sure, some missions are uninteresting, and the story and characters are somewhat disappointing, the melee combat sucks, but it makes up for it with its incredible gunfights and delightful atmosphere.

If you've been looking for a good PC third person shooter, look no further. I heavily recommend it if you can grab it on sale, especially the DLC missions, which fix most of the main game's issues.

reviewText:
I have to start out by saying that I love timepieces. With an educational background in history, I find myself drawn to games that have a historical setting. Mafia II is an excellent example.

Don't get me wrong, there was nothing historically astounding about the plotline itself but it was the setting that truly mattered. For the entirety of my first playthrough I was completely enthralled with  the mid-twentieth century mobster thing. I found myself really trying to slip into the story rather than running around capping civilians and robbing businesses, as is commonplace in similar titles. The time spent playing Mafia II thus far has been some of the most gratifying I have had while gaming within Steam.

I highly suggest this title to any fans of the GTA - esque genre and also to any individuals who enjoy immersing themselves in an entirely different era.

3 Thunbs Up!

reviewText:
Rating : 9/10

Definitely one of the BEST games I have played. Exceeded my expectations for a game produced in 2010 and I logged more hours than I intended too. Worth the while and money. Beautiful visuals, amazing plot, atmospheric, game play, always driving you forward to find out the next bit.

Vito Scaletta; An Italian immigrant in which emigrates with his family from Sicilia only a few years after
being born in 1925. Vito and his family had moved to Empire Bay in hopes of rebuilding their lives, only to discover they were no better off there than they were in Sicily. While still only being a Schoolboy, Vito gets involved into a life of crime with his best friend; Joe Barbaro. Vito is arrested during a botched robbery and is provided with two choices; Be drafted into the military, or go to prison. After serving his time in his Sicily, Vito returns home after being shot only to discover that his family now resides with large amounts of debt due to his Father borrowing money off a loan shark.

+ Top notch voice acting for all characters. Characters demonstrate emotion and personality.
+ Atmospheric, Story rich.
+ Excellent plot and development of characters.
+ Beautiful, sleek vehicles in which respond accordingly to the environment.
+ Vehicle handing is realistic and smooth.
+ Suave apparel.
+ On point rag doll physics.
+ Destruction physics.
+ Accurate, and detailed reloading animations.
+ Detailed character models.
+ Beautiful music with out most integrity. REAL music.
+ Medium sized map. Although does not compare to competitors.
+ Ability to interact with Enforcment. Providing the option to bribe, pay the fine, or to resist.
+ Cover system. Although it may be linear, it is essential for your survival and would be impossible to operate without it.
+ Sound for all weapons sound amazing and have a kick to them that is appealing.
+ Great port. All controls are fluid and function perfectly.

- Lack of free roam.
- Color palette. Although the color palette is vibrant, I feel as if the city itself possesses too much blandness. Don't know if the Developers had intended for that, but it bothers me.
- Cliff hanger ending.
- Derpy AI. At times the opposing faction Gangsters or Police are linear and don't process their environment.
- Houses. I found that since you are always wound up participating in the story, your house doesn't provide as much use as I had hoped. It seems to me that your house is provided basically to access your phone.

reviewText:
This game is a well written, well told story of a man named Vito Scaletta who starts his life in poverty and gets sent away to America from Sicily. He was a soldier in the army and due to a bullet that hit him, he gets sent back home and he gets caught up in a life of crime, and that's where you start. That's about enough of the backstory. Where is the review?

Story: 10/10
The story is excellent. I've seen stories that just make me feel what the protagonist feels. This game is one of them. With so many confusing and heartbreaking moments, as well as the great and memorable moments, you get a well-written storyline in the Era of the Mafia.

Sound: 9/10
The sound could be a little better (ahem, music). The gunshots, ambience and other noises sound pretty realistic, but ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, the people back in the day had a pretty bad taste in music, if I do say so myself. If you like the music, great. I'm not trying to offend anyone. But, if you don't, join the club. We got jackets!

Graphics: 10/10
Truly elite graphics that are perfect in (mostly) every way. There's a flaw where you slide into cover and your jacket gets all glitchy... but that's no matter. The cars look spectacular, and there's a variety of them. Blood looks meh. It's amazing and gory in the cutscenes, however, while playing, the blood looks... I don't know how to put it... gooey. I think it's a great graphics game, overall. Despite some flaws.

Gameplay: 8/10
This game has great controlling and mechanics. It handles well, there are a few stupid, annoying incidents when you're driving a car on the rails at full speed ahead and you slam into some protrusion that instantly kills you. This game would get a better score had it had more open world features. Once you complete the game, you don't get a free-roam mode. That's going to be explained in the Replay Value of this review. Note: I'll be as vague as possible, but you lose all your things 3 times within the game, so don't expect to keep all of your weapons, clothes, or cash even. Cash is easy to get back, relatively. Weapons and clothes, you can just steal from shops. It's no big deal, but it's a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.


Replay Value: 4/10
There are some missions where you can ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up, but there's not much of them. You can replay chapters, that's a step up, but when you complete the game, there is absolutely no free roam mode. Again, you can replay chapters that have free-roam mode available, and don't get me wrong, there's alot of times you can free roam, but I wish they'd just make a feature where after you complete the game, you get to do whatever you want.

Overall Rating Value: 8.2/10
This is a great game overall, but don't expect it to be too much of Grand Theft Auto... because it's not. There's one DLC for this game, and it's just 2 new clothes with different colors. I'd recommend this game to anyone craving action, and can take the annoying moments that are in Mafia II. Again, it's one helluva game and it has a lot of things in it.

reviewText:
What an awesome experience. I recently played Sleeping Dogs and thought that it gave a great insight into Triad culture but it pales in comparison to Mafia II. I really can't find fault with this game at all. I suppose you could say it only lasts 10 or so Hours but its a very intense 10 hours.

You play the role of Vito an Italian/American who with his buddy Joe takes his shot at becoming a Made man in the Mafia.
I can't really say much about the story without giving big spoilers but lets just say it gives us an excellent look at how life in the mob would actually be. I always wanted to play a game version of Goodfella's and Mafia II is just that.

+ Graphics still hold up today. The character models and expressions are great.

+ Old 50's music, i personally love the period and setting.

+ The Story has so many twists and turns, its better than many movies. Keeps you playing to see what happens.

+ The gameplay is also fantastic, its unforgiving unlike many shooters you need to use cover or you die.

- It comes to an end a little after 10 hours. I wanted more.

- You can no longer buy it on Steam. Get a copy elsewhere its really worth it!.

reviewText:
Despite the popular tag on the storepage, Mafia II is not much of an open world game. There's little to do and even less incentive to do it (aside from listening to the great soundtrack). It is, instead, a very linear, narrative-focused cover-based shooter - and thankfully a good one.

Although the open-world trappings lead to annoyances (tedious driving, with increasingly flimsy excuses for you to drive someone else's car, searches for collectables in the middle of a tense mission, etc), the solid atmosphere, writing, voice acting and graphics make the game a worthwhile experience overall.

The plot features some neat twists and is surprisingly adult at times - that's not necessarily a good or bad thing, but at least it is pushing the boundaries further than many games dare.

I didn't find it as memorable as the original game, but it's definitely a solid follow-up. It looks and sounds great, runs smoothly and offers a reasonably compelling story. Worth a go.

reviewText:
Such a great game that I am more than happy to have invested time in. Not only is the story great and driven, the characters are substantial, witty and comprehensible with voice overs that are simply over the top. The game itself is beautiful, and very enjoyable. The cops do tend to become really tedious with all the speeding limits/tickets and minor hit and runs, but the interactive choices in the game is realistic in a sense. To dragging bodies so you can dispose them to pick locking cars. Which is never a bad thing for these types of games I guess.

Having company with the likes of Joe throughout the game is also extremely enjoyable. Beside Vito (who is the main character) Joe, Vito's pal - is my favorite. He's uplifting, loyal and funny. He made this game much more enjoyable for me to play. The game does give you a L.A Noire and GTA feel, but it's also original and satisfying in its own way too. You don't have as much freeroaming as GTA and RDR though. With a bunch of money in the game that's useless to spend. Of course you can upgrade your car and buy a few outfits, but that's pretty much it. Not many fun spots to visit either, other than food joints, gas stations and shops.

But you're so focus on the main story that you end up not caring. This game certainly had a lot of thought on the story and is for sure a worth playing game to buy. Also, has one of the best stories in a game in my opinion and definitely improved itself from part one. Hopefully a third one comes out!

Rating : 9/10

Definitely one of the BEST games I have played. Exceeded my expectations for a game produced in 2010 and I logged more hours than I intended too. Worth the while and money. Beautiful visuals, amazing plot, atmospheric, game play, always driving you forward to find out the next bit.

Vito Scaletta; An Italian immigrant in which emigrates with his family from Sicilia only a few years after
being born in 1925. Vito and his family had moved to Empire Bay in hopes of rebuilding their lives, only to discover they were no better off there than they were in Sicily. While still only being a Schoolboy, Vito gets involved into a life of crime with his best friend; Joe Barbaro. Vito is arrested during a botched robbery and is provided with two choices; Be drafted into the military, or go to prison. After serving his time in his Sicily, Vito returns home after being shot only to discover that his family now resides with large amounts of debt due to his Father borrowing money off a loan shark.

+ Top notch voice acting for all characters. Characters demonstrate emotion and personality.
+ Atmospheric, Story rich.
+ Excellent plot and development of characters.
+ Beautiful, sleek vehicles in which respond accordingly to the environment.
+ Vehicle handing is realistic and smooth.
+ Suave apparel.
+ On point rag doll physics.
+ Destruction physics.
+ Accurate, and detailed reloading animations.
+ Detailed character models.
+ Beautiful music with out most integrity. REAL music.
+ Medium sized map. Although does not compare to competitors.
+ Ability to interact with Enforcment. Providing the option to bribe, pay the fine, or to resist.
+ Cover system. Although it may be linear, it is essential for your survival and would be impossible to operate without it.
+ Sound for all weapons sound amazing and have a kick to them that is appealing.
+ Great port. All controls are fluid and function perfectly.

- Lack of free roam.
- Color palette. Although the color palette is vibrant, I feel as if the city itself possesses too much blandness. Don't know if the Developers had intended for that, but it bothers me.
- Cliff hanger ending.
- Derpy AI. At times the opposing faction Gangsters or Police are linear and don't process their environment.
- Houses. I found that since you are always wound up participating in the story, your house doesn't provide as much use as I had hoped. It seems to me that your house is provided basically to access your phone.

reviewText:
*I've had countless hours of clockage of this game on PS3 so don't worry about my Steam time!*

Mafia II is burdened by the fact that it is a game - and maybe not even a very good one. But Mafia II is also one of the greatest games I have ever played. A here's why.

Mafia II is your basic Italian steroetype mobsters versus some other gangs flick. The gameplay is fairly simple, shoot and cover and make your way from point A to point B, nothing special. However, Mafia II is beautifully directed, acted and designed. The attention to period detail is fantastic, and the character interactions and story are absolutley fantastic. Mafia II would suit much better as being a movie or TV show, because all in all it is a cinematic experience and I would even go as far to say a cinematic masterpiece.

Mafia II has such a heart-pumping and wrenching narrative that really makes up for the sub-par gameplay mechanics and the lack of a traditional free play" mode. At face value
date: this game may not seem much to you. But I assure you the sale price it is at right now is WELL worth the price and is an absoloute steal. Since it's release
recommended:
Mafia II has never really left me and the announcement of Mafia III is just as much a reason to pick up this game than any.

+ Cinematic experience that is golden

9/10"

EDIT!! The rest of my review still applies, but I was in such an enamored mood I completely neglected to point out the fact that this game crashes CONSTANTLY. In an average session of play, I will have to force close and restart the game around 3 or 4 times. The gameplay (when it works) is still as great as I describe below, but the crashing may be too much for some people.

So very awesome, but don‚Äôt expect GTA 1942.

I don‚Äôt quite know how it happened, but I wanted to play Mafia II the instant I saw the very first trailer for it yet never picked it up because I was waiting for a really strong sale. Fast forward to about a week ago and as I was browsing my Steam Library getting organized something caught my eye: Mafia II was right there! Hanging out in my inventory just begging to be played!

I don‚Äôt know when I got it or where I got it from but to be honest I‚Äôm actually glad that I didn‚Äôt play it until just now. Mafia II (contrary to my initial impressions of it) is not just a 40‚Äôs gangster skin over a GTA clone, but I think it serves it really well. While it is true the world is entirely open and you‚Äôre free to do as you please for the most part, the game itself is entirely linear. Rather than banking on a robust sandbox, Mafia II tells a fantastic narrative and allows you to live through your own mob film. With GTA V still going strong, I didn‚Äôt need another sandbox crime game, so Mafia II really filled this awesome sweet spot between a 100 hour sandbox mayhem binge and a 4 hour third person spunkgargleweewee.

Don‚Äôt expect Grand Theft Forties, but definitely play this game!

reviewText: One of the most complex love hate relationships i've ever had with a game. Aesthetically speaking it's excellent, this is a good looking game and I love the period it's set in, the cars and the music all fantastic. The weapons have real bite, the cars have real weight and the voice acting has conviction. But this game is filled with litle niggles which on their own wouldn't bother me, but there are so many of them that it really bogs down the experience. The sparsity of checkpoints is easily the worst problem, the number of times i've been killed while behind solid cover is a joke and the car controls are far too twitchy, making a complete mockery of the game's fantastic physics model. What I really hate is that pretty much all of these problems feel like they could of been ironed out with a little more work from the developers, this is by no means a bad game but it doesn't feel like a polished product.

reviewText:
Great game, amazing, but short story, meh ending... it leaves many questions unanswered and Mafia III isn't looking like it's gonna answer them... it's quite clear that Mafia III is a new beginning.

Driving is awesome. I only played in the simulation mode and at high all speeds it was quite terrifying.
Controls... there 3 mouse sensitivity settings and only medium worsks as it should so I gave up, rented an excavator, and digged out my Xbox 360 controller unused for ages. Shooting with a controller wasn't that bad, aim assist is just pointing crosshair at ememy's head when you pull the left trigger, but it isn't following him / locked onto him.

Story is short, there is an achievement for driving a 50 miles with a single car and I barely managed to get it even after doing 15 laps of long, straight bridge, rest was just playing the game with not always my car being available. Won't write anything more, won't spoil, even though it's a 6 year old game.

Weapons. There is a Tommy Gun in 2 variants, M1A1 (clip mag - 30 rounds) and 1928 (drum mag -  50 rounds). Anyway, it features a Tommy Gun and that's everything you need to know about weapons in this game. Everything apart from it, M1 Garand and the bolt action thing is garbage (exluding pistols)... I found Tommy Gun spray more effective than a shotgun, especially against multiple enemies.
Cars, with all the DLCs there is almost 50 of them and all of them can run out of fuel - I love it, but not everybody might like that. In simulation mode the slides are terrifying - I was actually able to drift with a truck at 40 mph (in the summer, no snow).

Lack of free roam kinda sucks... all you can do is ignore the objective and go do some stuff.

This game... isn't worth it's price. I grabbed it at -80% on sale and with all DLCs (Aside from Jimmy's Vendetta and this other one), it was 8 Euro well spent. Nice game.

Some things that happened to me when playing the game...

They're quite funny, although reading about them may not be as funny.
After finishing the chapter, going home, I drove into a tree at a speed of 30 mph, and somehow it accelerated to over 125 mph in 0,5 sec, because I got Pedal to the Metal achievement then. And, of course I died and had to drive there again.

After I sold gas things on gas stations, I drove through a long and straight bridge, 100 mph... snowy road... hit the wall... you have been killed... start the whole mission again, because this game lacks checkpoints a bit. 11/10 would drive into a wall again.

reviewText: I saw this game in the store after forgetting about it for several years. I played the demo back when I had an Xbox 360 and I've wanted it since then. When I saw it on sale for like 7 dollars and all the dlc for an additional 7 or so, I immediately bought it all. I literally played the game for 9 hours yesterday when I bought it. It plays like a movie and the story is really involved. The driving takes a bit of getting used to since the cars of from the 40's and 50's and since the first part of the game takes place during the winter. The game does really well with teaching you things, there are no ugly pop up windows with hints. For example, in the very first mission, you walk to Joe's house and hear a wife yelling at her husband as he tries to fix their car. Eventually he gets mad and leaves, at which point you can fix the car for the wife. It's not like a cut scene, and if you had stolen a car instead of walking there, you would have never even seen it. Like I said, this game is like a movie that you play. I don't know if there are choices you can make, like at one point there was a prison fight that I lost, and I don't know if that had any affect on the story. Definately buy the DLC if you buy the game, the cars in game are really slow and not much fun to drive, but if you get the Greasers pack you get a few hot rods that are a blast to drive. Overall, this game is an absolute masterpiece and I can't wait to play Mafia III.

reviewText:
After seeing the trailers and gameplay for Mafia III i decided to purchase Mafia II and see what all the fuss was about. Luckily, it was on sale for ‚Ç¨5.99 instead of its original ‚Ç¨29.99 . Needless to say that the price I purchased it for was a steal. The game features great 'car-feel', shoot-outs, interesting characters and story. Let me explain each one in detail.

'Car-Feel'
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Driving a car in this game was beautiful. It made me feel like I was actually in the 1940's and 50's. Cars are also a big part of the story as well. Since you can't take a taxi and the map is not too big, you get the great pleasure of driving everywhere, this may be in the finest of sports cars or the most beat-down piece of crap you can find, its your choice.

Shoot-Outs
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
As there was in real life, there are plenty of shoot-outs or gang wars which occur throughout the story in the game. Each shoot-out is unique because you are in a different area every time and if it is not in an area you are familiar with, you truly feel like you can die at any moment, and you can! Although it does use the classic 'Stand-behind-cover-and-all-health-regen' mechanic, one shot to the head will kill you! Shotguns one-shot you and Tommy guns ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you!

Interesting Characters
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Throughout the game you meet a very wide array of characters, bad guys and... good guys? It seems like every character in the game is a nice guy to the main protagonist, Vito, in the beginning but then they turn into real snakes :(
Everyone wants to climb higher in the mob and will do anything for it. Besides snakes, there is also Joe. Joe is the most loyal friend you will ever encounter... Even more than real life :) :) :/ :(

Story
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The story in Mafia II... is the best story I have ever seen in all my time of playing video games and I genuinely think it should be the sole reason someone should buy this game. There are plenty of memorable characters and moments. The story follows Vito Scaletta, an italian American man who comes home from war and gets himself involved with all the mobs in the city by doing work for them and trys to make a name for himself.

Quick Summary: Small open world game with an engaging story, though the gunplay is mediocre. The game is very story driven so despite the fact that you can drive all over the city, you can‚Äôt really ‚Äúdo‚Äù anything (no significant side quests or minigames). Still, it‚Äôs definitely worth playing.

You play Vito Scalletta, a World War 2 vet come home early from the Italian front, with connections to organized crime in the city. You don‚Äôt want to break your back working for chump change like your father, so you turn to petty crime, making friends in low places. The story takes place over at least a decade so you experience the various highs and lows of joining a criminal enterprise, though interestingly I don‚Äôt remember the word ‚Äúmafia‚Äù being used significantly. Instead, you throw your allegiance behind one of 3 ‚Äúfamilies‚Äù running the crime in the city of Empire Bay. As you‚Äôd expect among a bunch of crooks, the families aren‚Äôt satisfied with sharing the city, and underworld war is coming.

The game is played in third person perspective similar to Sleeping Dogs or Grand Theft Auto, and just like those games, you‚Äôll be spending a lot of time in cars driving around the city. Being that the game takes place in the mid 1900‚Äôs the cars aren‚Äôt that fast so it actually takes some time to travel around. Also, the city‚Äôs main highway isn‚Äôt very well developed, so once you get on, you kind of have to follow it to the end (no exits along the way). As I mentioned earlier, the game city isn‚Äôt all that large, and there‚Äôs not too much to do other than search for collectibles. Unlike the Saint‚Äôs Row games, there are very few diversions to spend your time on, although you can rob the few stores in the city for some easy money (don‚Äôt bother). Causing trouble (like robbery or running people over) will get the cops on you, but most of the time you can just outrun them and they‚Äôll forget you exist.

Combat in the game uses a regenerating health meter and you only have a few guns to choose from. Generally I found the semi-auto pistols easier to get headshots with, and you hide behind cover for protection while waiting for your health to refill. There is a little hand to hand combat, but it‚Äôs very simple (light punch, Heavy punch, and Dodge) and mostly used for story based fights. Most of your regular fighting will be with guns.

Pros:
+Very interesting story, with characters you can get invested in.
+Spend some time with the collectible nudie mags

Cons:
-The game has an unusual check point save system where it doesn‚Äôt really save your progress unless you progress on the main story. That means if you spend a lot of time out in the city trying to make money and get killed by cops, you‚Äôll very likely lose everything you gained since the last story checkpoint.
-The game DLC‚Äôs are no longer being sold on Steam at this time.

Overall, the game is definitely worth a playthrough. Don‚Äôt bother trying to hoard up money because you don‚Äôt really have anything to spend it on other than a couple of car upgrades.

reviewText: This is most likely one of the best story driven games I've played in some time...\nI know I'm definitely late to the party playing this game...5 years late, actually, but I would beyond recommend this game to anyone who likes story based games, who like action games (or shooters in general), and would recommend this game to any who are interested in crime games too (GTA series fans, I think, would love this game). To be honest, as far as story goes, I liked this story better than, I think, any other story in a game I've played. I truly believe it's that good. I could actually get attached to the characters in this story. There were a couple parts in the game that actually got me pretty good (and I most generally never get emotional in movies, let alone video games). Please, if you're thinking about getting this on sale, don't think about it, just get it, I believe it's more than worth it. Now, there were several graphical issues I encountered, as far as technical stuff goes. I was getting lower framerates than I should have (I'm running on an Athlon X4 860K and a Radeon R7 260X) and I was also getting some glitchy textures as well. I think this must have to do with the game being optimised for Nvidia, but there are several fixes out there for these problems, none of which worked for me, but I toughed through it, and was glad I could get past it.

reviewText:
Gameplay:
Mafia II has some of the best gameplay aspects in a sandbox game, and is by far one of my favourite games. The game features classical cars, weapons, music and a various of other things from the 1940's - 1950's era. The game has a variety of cool features, like feeling your car up with gas, opening and closing windows, robbing stores, modifying your vehicles, stealing cars, lock picking locks, climb through windows and various other things like that nature. Mafia II mainly focuses on the story driven gameplay rather that petty side missions that distract you from the story (like grand theft auto.) so people that love a good story I strongly recommend picking this game up. I love mafia games and mafia films, and this was just perfect and I am hoping they release another one. If you get bored within game you can collect some Playboy posters (which actually show nudity, I think their are 50 of them.) you can also collect wanted posters and other collectable items to keep you interested, I managed to collect and play as it was fun anyway and I did not get bored. I have played the game both on consoles and PC and love them on both, obviously I had a better time on pc since the higher frame rates and better graphics but it was still an awesome experience on console.


Graphics:
Mafia II; now this game just has overwhelming graphical aspects and visuals(especially for the time the game was released.) The game features awesome dynamic lighting, 3D Rendered models and high resolution textures. When playing the game my breath was taken away with the graphics. It included amazing reflections, no frame drops and feels like a solid build. I can't really explain the graphics other than they are some of the best visuals I have seen in a sandbox game; I'll prove that later on when I post some screen shots. The game runs of the Illusion Engine with PhysX, even though I have an AMD graphics card the game still did it's job and created an amazing experience. The game also uses real time cutscenes which are created by the Illusion Engine so they are not pre-rendered cutscenes, so if you have a half broken car, it will show that in the cutscene which is pretty awesome if you ask me. Some scenes are pre rendered such as the hotel explosion.

Ratings:
Gameplay: 10/10
Graphics: 9/10
Controls: 10/10
Plot: 9/10
Overall: 10/10

Conclusion:
Mafia 2 is one of the best game I have ever played; it's definitely worth buying and I would advise you buy it on pc, if you have a good enough pc that is... but console still gives an amazing experience nonetheless.

reviewText:
Playing this game you truly feel like a italian boy growing up in america, stepping into organized crime with your childhood friend.

The story is very intriguing, worthy of a Martin Scorsese movie, and the gameplay is incredibly entertaining. It has good anf fun missions with a deacent variety, that always pushes the story forward. But the most fun part of the gameplay for me was defenitly the vast, open world with incredible 50s style cars, weapons and surroundings. I must admit that I am a huge fan of mafia stories in general, so I might be a bit biased, but I've had more fun with this open world than I've had with any other game of this type that I can think of (althoug I have yet to try out GTA V).

The game also has a good amount of comedy thrown into the writing, thoug it mostly stays a serious crime drama. There are no major bug that I encounderd during my multiple playthrougs. The gunplay is nothing special but I never really got bored of it, and you get to chose between more guns than you would expect from a 1950s game, with multiple guns, assult rifles and other types of weapons. A molotov cocktail is also always a big bonus in my book.

Combining the deep story that kept you on the edge the entire time with a great payoff with the fantastic shooting/driving gameplay that you would expect from this type of game, it is most certenly a really enjoeble ride that will provide hours of gameplay even after the story is finished throug the open world.

7/10

Feel free to check out my other reviews.

reviewText:
Playing this game is nearly the next best thing to watching yourself starring in your own gangster movieI. Suspect that after waiting 8 years for the sequel of amazing Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven everyone was expecting something truly special. And in my opinion the game lives up to the expectations: the story line is great, the characters are believable, the scenery, cars and music really take you back to 1950's. Less positive reviews read that the game is too short - I disagree. I believe that the concept of the game was to be more of an interactive movie rather than typical shoot'em-up. Of course, if you set the difficulty to low and lock yourself in the room with a bag of microvawable meals you can finish the game in one sitting, but that's not the point. This game is not for blood hungry kids who shoot before they think all day long! It's very thought through, well composed piece of interactive software that mature gamers with limited gaming time can enjoy for good couple of weeks. I myself finished it in a month playing one chapter every other day. And I enjoyed every moment of it!
Few people try to compare it to GTA IV. I played GTA IV, and it is far more complexed game with larger world and loads more missions, but I would not put them in the same category. Playing GTA you can easily loose track of the main story line engaging in other side missions" - Mafia focuses strongly on linear story which is far more gripping. The only negative thing I can say about the story is that the main twist isn't too convincing and happens far to abruptly.
Some other negative things are:
- driving any car is quite a task
date: but all the cars of the era were RWD and had no ESP so it would be pretty difficult turning corners at speed
recommended: \n- police are somewhat inconsistent i.e. when you jump red lights or are wanted and some of them ignore you totally.\nOverall the game is almost perfect. Few niggles here and there
hoursPlayed: but it is great! I recommend it to any mature gamer."

reviewText:
Mr. Salieri sends his regards......

I was always fascinated with the Mafia. Maybe it was the power, the families, the tuxedos or the tommy gun blasting away as they slowly walked down the hallway. The overall badass-ery of the Italian mobsters is a force to be reckoned with.

The game revolves around Vito Scaletta and Joe Barbaro, best friends who work their way up to the top of the Mafia. The story is great, with what you'd expect from a mobster game. Full of obstacles, pain, suffering and betrayal. The game itself feels depressing and it really suits the mood, plus I really felt conflicted with the ending.......

Gameplay is just a breeze. gunfights look amazing, with realistic destruction as the bullets hit concrete, tiles, blocks, wine bottles and stuff. The cover system is also top-notch, although sometimes I'll run into the wrong cover, which causes me to die -_- Driving is ok, since the cars handle heavily and cops will fine/arrest/kill you if you do a number of traffic violations.

Overall Experience: I love this game, but it could have been better. The main menu music is honestly one of the best I've heard and absolutely fits in with the theme. It's definitely worth a look if you love a good story and fantastic open-world gameplay.

reviewText:
In my opinion Mafia II is one of the most criminally (pun intended) underrated games of the last decade. The game is set in the fictional American city of Empire Bay during the heady 1940's and 50's, a time when American pride and racial segregation were at an all time high. The plot follows young World War II veteran Vito Scalleta and his buddy/sidekick Joe Barbaro. It chronicles their rise and fall through the hierachy of the American Mafia. The narrative is very good and expertly structured despite the fact it relies on mobster movie cliches a little to much. The game features a wide cast of characters almost all of which are incredibly rich and interesting. Of particular interest is the Walter White esque character arc of Vito as he finds himself forced to abandon his morals as he becomes further and further entrenched in the underworld.  When it comes down to it Mafia II is a story about choices (despite the fact the player never makes any) and consequences. And there are many for Vito and his family and friends.

But the real star of the show is of Empire Bay itself. It is incredibly detailed and a quite simply extraordinary recreation of 50's New York city complete with steaming manholes, coffee shops, towering office buildings, and a wide array beautiful era faithful cars blaring 50's tunes. The interiors are just as meticulously detailed looking just like sets ripped straight from the TV series Mad Men".  it is a tour de force in world building and arguably in the benchmark when it comes to open world cities. (Yes despite Grand Theft Auto V)

Empire Bay is an open world yet features no fast travel mechanic. Whenever you need to get somewhere you drive
date: which is where the aforementioned cars come into their own. Some players will no doubt find this rather tedious but I personally enjoyed it and used it as an excuse to see the sights and explore. The driving mechanics are slightly more finnicky than othr games but that can no doubt be attributed to the period setting. The shooting and brawling sequences are all handled with aplomb but are curiously few and far between
recommended: with only the occasional burst of ultra violence to please action junkies. Interestingly despite the open world setting there is actually next to nothing to do outside of the main storyline. In a game like GTA or Saints Row this would be a calamity but in Mafia II it only serves to put the focus on the excellent central narrative. Mafia II is excellent
hoursPlayed: brilliantly written and crafted game.  A game with real heart and soul. Highly recomended."

reviewText:
Mafia II immerses you right away in the 40ies/50ies era.  It is a beautiful game that is closer to an action game than a GTA like.  Technically it was outstanding for when it came out.  However, it is not the unforgettable experience that I was waiting for.  The story line was not as fleshed out as what I hoped for (I played the first Mafia and loved it. I am also a huge fan of the Godfather anthology, Scarface, and other mafia classics...)

My take away is that 2K Czech has done it's best developing the 40ies/50ies atmosphere and story line and I salute their work in doing so.  However, this game is really inferior to the older/first Mafia.  I hope they will learn from this experience and produce an outstanding Mafia III.

Verdict: B-/C+

reviewText:
Get this game and the Jimmy's Vendetta DLC, I suggest that DLC because it acts like a sandbox/free ride mode and allows you to save at homes/safehouses. Hours of fun, hectic firefights with destructible objects (The game even comes with PhysX options) and lots of detail. Window panes shatter and shards fly out with each bullet, with wooden chips flying about as they fire at you and miss and hit the wall causing tons of little pieces of wood and plaster to fly off. The aftermath is crazy, floors covered in shards of glass and other debris, bullet holes everywhere and objects torn apart, window blinds swinging slightly in the wind with cop sirens heard in the distance... It's a shame that the main game was relatively linear and only allowed for SOME exploration, but when you're not on a singleplayer mission, the experience of freeroaming is like drinking eggnog after that long wait... The problem is if you die you restart at a checkpoint and there's no safehouse saving so don't expect any GTA stuff right out of the box, you'll have to either buy the Jimmy's Vendetta DLC, Joe's Adventure DLC, or install the working Freeride mod which is not as good as the DLC but it kinda works...
You can vault over certain objects and climb onto cars, you can pick the locks of parked cars or just smash their windows which creates some of that fancy PhysX glass shard debris which gets on your hood and falls off nicely as you turn and narrowly make it around the bend to continue your wacky spree.
You can become wanted and you have to change your clothing or you'll probably be shot on sight, your current vehicle can also become wanted and you'll have to bail, or just be careful and sneak past the patrolling cruisers and on-foot police officers. There are also gang members that if you gun down one of their buds, nearby gangbangers will retaliate and fire upon you, you can also simply provoke them and get the cops to arrest them while hiding out of sight.
You can purchase items from stores and even rob the cash register of 90% of stores except for the 2 special vendors and vehicle modification shops (Which I forgot to mention can remove the wanted variable by changing your plate and repainting your vehicle).
There was also this one store with 2 entrances and big ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• windows and you can drive your car through the entire thing, like it was straight out of a film or something.
This game features a great story and it was the first time I actually gave a damn about any character's problems (in a game).

It looks just as good as GTA 5, and... IT HAS A PC VERSION!

reviewText:
I did a review on this game on a site a couple of months ago so here we go:

Gameplay:
Mafia II has some of the best gameplay aspects in a sandbox game, and is by far one of my favourite games. The game features classical cars, weapons, music and a various of other things from the 1940's - 1950's era. The game has a variety of cool features, like feeling your car up with gas, opening and closing windows, robbing stores, modifying your vehicles, stealing cars, lock picking locks, climb through windows and various other things like that nature. Mafia II mainly focuses on the story driven gameplay rather that petty side missions that distract you from the story (like grand theft auto.) so people that love a good story I strongly recommend picking this game up. I love mafia games and mafia films, and this was just perfect and I am hoping they release another one. If you get bored within game you can collect some Playboy posters (which actually show nudity, I think their are 50 of them.) you can also collect wanted posters and other collectable items to keep you interested, I managed to collect and play as it was fun anyway and I did not get bored. I have played the game both on consoles and PC and love them on both, obviously I had a better time on pc since the higher frame rates and better graphics but it was still an awesome experience on console.


Graphics:
Mafia II; now this game just has overwhelming graphical aspects and visuals(especially for the time the game was released.) The game features awesome dynamic lighting, 3D Rendered models and high resolution textures. When playing the game my breath was taken away with the graphics. It included amazing reflections, no frame drops and feels like a solid build. I can't really explain the graphics other than they are some of the best visuals I have seen in a sandbox game; I'll prove that later on when I post some screen shots. The game runs of the Illusion Engine with PhysX, even though I have an AMD graphics card the game still did it's job and created an amazing experience. The game also uses real time cutscenes which are created by the Illusion Engine so they are not pre-rendered cutscenes, so if you have a half broken car, it will show that in the cutscene which is pretty awesome if you ask me. Some scenes are pre rendered such as the hotel explosion.

Ratings:
Gameplay: 10/10
Graphics: 9/10
Controls: 10/10
Plot: 9/10
Overall: 10/10

Conclusion:
Mafia 2 is one of the best game I have ever played; it's definitely worth buying and I would advise you buy it on pc, if you have a good enough pc that is... but console still gives an amazing experience nonetheless. I know the review has already been made but I felt like he did not do it justice; also thank you for your feedback and thank you for reading my review, I am really trying hard to achieve that Game Reviewer Badge and I also love playing games and going over them it's really cool to express your feelings on that game.

reviewText: Let me say that I really enjoyed this game. It's telling a great mafia story. Here are a few reasons I like this game. 1. It has solid and smooth gameplay. It varies between mainly driving, shooting, and excellent hand to hand combat. Though there are a few glitches that can vary from small bugs, into a glitch that prevents you form completing a mission. This has a nice open world with plenty of places to either shop at, or rob. Which brings me to another point, there are quite a few ways to earn money outside of the main story. The police system in this feels very authentic: if you drive past the speed limit, they fine you. If you get caught with a gun they arrest you, etc. The missions can give some tedious objectives but I didn't mind so much because it was relavent to the story and it felt all the more authentic. There is a large number of cars that you can slightly customize (license plate, paint job, handling, rims). There are also usually a number of collectables to find throughout levels and the world. There is also a good soundtrack that fits the era well and sets a good tone. I just wish that you could explore the world after you complete the story. 2. The Story in this is a memorable mafia story that takes inspiration from films like Goodfellas. It has alot of good characters. The story is presented through good voice acting and interesting cutscenes. The only real problem I have with the story is how nabruptly it ends, of course it is in true mafia movie theme so I can either say the ending was abrupt or brilliant. 3. The graphics may be this game's weakest point, not to say they're god awful, but some parts are just sub-par while other aspects look good and bad. Character models for people like Vito and Joe (the main characters) are pretty good while others look mediocre. I saw a few background characters that almost looked like they were recycled from the first Mafia game. The world looks great, with a decent sized map. Cars look very good as well.\nSo overall I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of mafia movies or action games or period pieces. If you don`t care very much about graphics then you will find that this gets the job done. The gameplay doesnt really add much but it works well and keeps the game above being generic.

reviewText:
Truly an excellent and highly immersive game.

It's an open world city game similar to a grand theft auto title, only it takes place at the tail end of WW2 and beyond, in the New York mob. Great story, great acting, great action, beautiful graphics. I was hooked by the beginning in which you're a WW2 veteran returning home for Christmas for a short reprieve, the combination of the rich snow filled Christmas atmosphere in New York combined with the themes of WW2 patriotism were everywhere... And of course, my mob buddies pulled strings to keep me from shipping back out to war...

My only criticism is that it's replay value isn't particularly high, not like a grand theft auto game where you can jump in a year later and just start blowing things up and finding mini-games... But if you've never played this, then you need to change that immedietely.

reviewText: Born the son of a poor immigrant, Vito is a beaten down Italian American who is trying to secure his piece of the American Dream. Looking to escape the life of poverty that consumed his childhood, Vito is soon swayed by the lure of power and wealth that a life of Organized Crime can bring. A petty criminal his whole life, Vito, along with his childhood friend, Joe, will descend into the world of Organized Crime. Together, they will work to prove themselves to the Mob as they try to make their names on the streets of a cold and unforgiving city. Mafia 2 immerses players in the mob underworld of a fictitious late 1940's / early 1950's scenario. The game engages you in a cinematic Hollywood movie experience in a living, breathing city, fusing high octane gunplay with white knuckle driving and an engaging narrative.

reviewText:
A truly underated title - this game just drips with exquisite story telling and ambience. Everything from the characters to the music, cars and clothing is finely detailed, to the point that you can even see 'Empire Bay' (a beautifully recreated New York) transform around you as you travel from the late 'War Time' 40's into the exciting 50's.

This game executes itself technically as well - it makes great use of Nvidia Physx, which in a gun fight can make the destructible enviroment really come to life. Believe me some scenes where you have mobsters blasting at each other with high powered SMG's can really feel like an intense firefight.

This is a game you really don't want to miss...

reviewText:
This game certainly grew on me. It's not the best open world game, but I really enjoyed my time playing it. The DLC is a must buy unfortunately, because free roam is very fun though not possible without DLC. The moment this game really got me is when the world changes - I don't want to spoil it - but you'll know what I mean when you see it.

-Story is decent, though ends on a very weak note. It is quite convoluted at times, however. Some plot points will leave you scratching your head
-The world is gorgeous
-Mafia II has the best driving mechanics I've ever played in anything that isn't a racing game
-Gunplay is reasonable

Unfortunately, some people will be expecting the city of Empire Bay to be more sandbox-y, and that is not what Mafia II is about. It's story is very linear and allows you to explore 'on a leash', if you will; either before or after a mission begins. DLC rectifies this, but you don't get to play as Vito. The DLC is also very weak compared to the actual campaign. You don't pay for small additions of what you'd see in the campaign; the DLC has no cutscenes for the missions, at least in Joe's Adventure. Everything is told to you via text before you accept or decline the mission. Very weak.

Overall, highly reccomended game, even though it has flaws - and it has many. Exploring and soaking in the world the developers have created is enough for me.

reviewText:
I would reccomend this game to anyone and everyone.

The game takes place in a LOT of different place as the story progresses, as well as taking place in different time periods: from the 1940's to the 50's (I think). I really loved the way the game changed: (without spoilers) when you are 'away' for a few years, everything is different when you come back: the cars are more advanced and faster.

The missions are fun and engaging, with a lot of variation and depth.

I adored the way the police were set out, very unlike GTA where they shoot on site for the smallest things, the punishments the police inflict are much more suited. E.G. If you are caught speeding (You have to be going very fast over the limit for them to pick up on it) you will be fined, same as if you were brawling on the streets or ramming other cars. But say you attack an officer, then they unleash their rage!

The only comaint i have about the game is, there is NO oppurtunity to have fun in the world and explore, yu are always on a mission. I assumed that you would be able to explore at the end, after you had got a lot of money and had a nice house etc. But, alas, no. Yes the ending was very powerful, but the game just ends. When you are in the villa, splash out and have some fun before continuing with the story, as that is proably one of the only times you will have an oppurtunity

Despite the drawback, i would rate this game an 9/10. Brilliant.

reviewText:
Mafia II is should be assessed on its own merits rather than in comparison to 'open world' shooters because it is not one. Yes you can drive and walk nearly everywhere, but there is little or no interaction between you the player and the open world.

Play Mafia as a Story driven shooter and it suddenly becomes a much better game. It does what it predecessor did at times better and sadly at times worse.

The looks, driving mechanics and gun play are a step above Mafia I. I enjoyed Mafia 1's game theme more but 2 has an great set of radio station music. The most glaring ommssion is the lack of free roam at the end of the game which Mafia One had out of the box; yes it is possible to buy a DLC to unlock free roam but that is really unfair


The ~10 hours or so I took to complete the game were thoroughly enjoyable as i was not expectnig a GTA clone, I was expecting a sequel to Mafia and I got what i was looking for, with the possible exception of free-roam
